story:
Hello friends!


I've been accepted to the 8 week-long New York Arts Practicum in Brooklyn this summer. The impetus behind this program is to provide participating artists with a supportive environment to address the challenges of life as an artist. Participants learn experientially in order to bridge their lives from being students into lives as artists in the world.

I will work with a mentor, Letha Wilson, in her studio two days per week, meet weekly for critique seminars, and for site visits in artist studios, galleries, and museums to discuss business, professional skills, and ways further develop the quality of artwork I am producing.

The New York Arts Practicum gives its participants the rare opportunity to meet and talk with professionals about models for negotiating a creative professional practice as an artist. The program also promotes the cultivation of professional relationships between mentors, gallerists, curators, New York based artists, as well as the other participants.

Participating in this program will benefit both my work and career. My work will be viewed and critiqued by other participants, guest artists, curators, and gallerists. This will develop the quality of my work and ability to write and speak about my concepts and research. Additionally, my career will be enhanced by creating a new community and network with the other participants and professionals I meet through the program.

The money raised through this campaign will be used to fund the cost of the program, housing, and travel.

More info about the New York Arts Practicum: www.artspracticum.org

HYPERALLERGIC, Alternative Art Education: http://hyperallergic.com/70686/in-search-of-an-alternative-art-education-altedu/

More about me and my work: www.jodiecavalier.com

More about Letha Wilson: http://lethaprojects.com/visuals/index.php

story:
Short Project Summary - Keep Dancing in the Sun Memorial Relief Fund

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • My name is Brian K. Hemphill. I'm a writer, music producer, lyricist, actor, published author, lecturer, and artistic coach. I also work as a project coordinator for a child abuse prevention education agency.
  • This campaign is important to me as a way to both promote the memory of a great friend and artist, while galvanizing community action around helping the victims of Hurricane Sandy. I want to promote the belief that Lené and I shared that art and music can promote awareness of vital causes and foster positive change. By giving away our song "Keep Dancing in the Sun," which is one of the songs on a tribute album in memory of Lené Newkirk who passed away before the album was completed, we can demonstrate that music can be a tool to foster positive change. The Lené Newkirk Keep Dancing in the Sun Memorial Relief Project will demonstrate this philosophy.
  •  For as little as $5.00, an individual can become a part of a great collective which can make a difference by improving the lives of victims of Hurricane Sandy. The target of $5,000 may seem small in comparison with the billions of dollars of destruction Sandy caused; however, this financial support will mean a world of difference to those families, individuals, and children receiving the financial support.
  • If you don't have a lot to contribute to this relief initiative, that's okay. Collectively, if people give what they can, the collective pool of even small donations can make a world of difference.

Breakdown of Perks and Incentrives

I set a target goal of $5,000 to be raised in the memory of Lené Newkirk. One hundred percent of the proceeds will go to trusted disaster relief organizations like American Red Cross or Save the Children. Donating this money in the name of my friend will promote his vocal legacy and compassion, while providing aide to the disaster victims of Sandy.

  • As this is a campaign to show that art can inspire community action, all the perks support the promotion of art. The first perk offered for a $5.00 contribution is a copy of "Keep Dancing in the Sun," a song written to encourage perseverance and hope. An abundance of perseverance and hope is the disaster victims of Hurricane Sandy will need to recover.
  • For a contribution of $15.00, supporters receive a special download code to download an mp3 version of the album on CDBaby.com. The memorial album, called Tribute, was finally released in Oct. 2012 on the 8th anniversary of his passing. The album contains 11 amazing songs. Several of the songs deal with issues like child abuse, racism, nuclear proliferation, and other timely issues. Other songs push the boundaries of musical experimentation. One song, for example, features a blues vocals over African drums and a heavy metal guitar. From pop, to rock, to new age jazz, there's certainly an eclectic mix of music for music lovers to appreciate.
  • For $25.00, contributors receive a physical cd of Tribute.
  • For $80.00, contributors receive an autograph copy of this author's book entitled The Elements of Creative and Expressive Artistry: A Philosophy for Creating Everything Artistic. This 600-page all-artist guide discloses the 9 root elements and 36 branch elements that make all artistic works expressive. The book offers great insights to performing artists, visual artists, and writers alike.
  • For $120, contributors get a hardcopy autographed copy of The Elements of Creative and Expressive Artistry: A Philosophy for Creating Everything Artistic. (See description above.)
  • For $250, contributors will get a two-hour conference call to discuss any aspect of art they would like. For others who may not have a particular topic, artistic coach and author Brian K. Hemphill will provide an overview of his book The Elements of Creative and Expressive Artistry. This will certainly prompt inquiries for discussion.
  • For $500, contributors will be recognized by name in the physical CD case underneath the memorial dedication inscription to Lene Newkirk. Contributors will receive a physical CD copy of Tribute, containing 11 diverse and eclectic songs.

I don't need to explain the importance of supporting this campaign. Everyone worldwide has seen photographs and heard personal narratives of how Sandy affected so many individuals. As a native New Yorker from Staten Island which faced major devastation and as a current resident of New Jersey where southern coastal municipalities were annihilated, I know I have to take some action. I was inconvenienced by Hurricane Sandy with a lost of power, heat, and water for a few days. So many others lost everything. As an artist, I have the sensitivity to empathize with the victims. As an executive with a strong background in project management, I have the skills to execute this campaign. Although I'm optimistic that we'll reach our target, whatever monies are raised will go to support disaster relief organizations. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute with cash, you can certainly contribute through word of mouth support and using social media to spread the word about this campaign. And that’s all there is to it. We're all members of a worldwide community and must do what we can help. Whatever you can do to support this campaign is appreciated.

story:
3 GRAND, 3 STAGES OF DEVELOPMENT, 3 WITCHES...

PLEASE SUPPORT THE WORK I FEEL I AM ON THIS PLANET TO MAKE.

Note: Donations over $500 will not be accepted…. Yes, this means you.

 

As most of you reading this will know, I dedicate much of my life to making theatre and am hugely passionate about the kind of theatre that I feel called to make.  Today I am reaching out with this fundraising campaign because I want to take a big, new step forward in the development of work with my company Rapid Descent.

 No company that I know of is making the kind of theatre that I want to bring into being, and in order to do this I need to not only create ‘IT’, but also create how the hell I am going to make ‘IT’. Despite having a talented and dedicated cast for Tartuffe,  (my last show) I was unhappy with the show itself, and in the soul searching I have done since I have formed the belief that the kind of work I want to make needs time and money for development, and at this stage in my life as an artist I also need to spend time and money developing process, which I will then use to make future shows.

 The other big and exciting step that I am taking is towards forming closer and more fruitful collaborations with other artists. I have always valued the contribution of other artists and I believe that collaboration is a vital key in the creation of the theatre I now dream of, so collaboration is a defining feature of the stages of development that I am inviting you to support today.

 

WHAT ARE THE 3 STAGES OF DEVELOPMENT?


As a supporter of this project, you get to chose which stage your money goes towards. After you have made a donation I will send you an email to say thank you and ask if you would like to fund a particular stage of development. Those stages are-

 

1.WORKING WITH AARON PRISKORN

The first stage of development is to work with Trumpet player/composer Aaron Priskorn. Aaron has been in both of the full-length shows that I have created here in San Francisco and is a truly gifted, classically trained trumpet player and composer. As well as playing live and composing for other instruments Aaron works with a loop station, which is an electronic device that enables him to layer the music that he plays live.  He and I have done some great work together so far and I am really excited to explore together further ways to create theatre that seamlessly combines live music with its other elements. For the first stage of development we will explore the creation of vocal scores performed by the cast, and begin our work creating some of the key theme tunes for Rapid Descent's Macbeth.

You can hear him in action at:  http://soundcloud.com/aaron-priskorn

 

2.WORKING WITH JONES WELSH

The second stage of development will focus on working with Choreographer Jones Welsh. I met Jones when I was in London and he is a wonderful dancer and choreographer who’s work combines grace with strength and athleticism.  He works with an LA company called Diavolo Dance Theater who create incredible shows on moving set pieces. In this development stage he and I will devise methods of working together, mainly with a chorus of performers, exploring ways of working with chorus and text. I am really excited about the prospect of working with Jones. I feel that Macbeth will greatly benefit from having a choreographer AND a director and our working relationship is such that I am confident together we will create work (and methods of making it) that combine movement and text in profound and poetic ways.

 You can see him in action at http://www.nortoncenter.com/previous-seasons/1-the-newlin-hall-series/206-diavolo-dance-theater

 

3.COMBINING THE ELEMENTS

In the third stage of development I will work with both Aaron and Jones and we will work on the scene between Macbeth and Lady Macbeth during which they kill King Duncan, and create a version that includes: live music, (both trumpet and vocal scores), movement (from Mac, Lady Mac and three witches who will be observing the scene),and Shakespeare’s text with it’s hair raising, pulse quickening poetry. We will create this scene to be a part of the future Rapid Descent production of Macbeth, planned for 2013.

 

 

WHY WON’T YOU TELL ME HOW MUCH TO DONATE?

I haven’t told you how much to donate because I trust you to know the right amount for you to donate. If you believe in the project and want to donate, just sit still for a moment and think about what the right amount is for you to give. I believe that the right amount is one that will make us both feel happy, you will feel happy and generous to give it and I will be super happy and grateful to receive it. Please do not donate an amount that makes you feel unhappy for any reason. 

All donations gratefully received, but DON’T FORGET the $500 limit. I would HATE to have to send you back your money because you thought the rules did not apply to you.....

 

WHAT HAPPENS IF THE CAMPAIGN DOESN’T REACH $3,000?

If we don’t reach our goal with this fundraiser, we don’t get the money, and your donation will not be processed.

CAN I SEND YOU A CHEQUE INSTEAD OF USING ONLINE PAYMENT?

Yes, please feel free to do this if it makes you more comfortable. Make the cheque out to Megan Finlay and post it to 1707 Dolores St San Francisco CA 94110.

story:
Short Summary

Have you been yearning to be the owner of original artwork? Please join My Myriad Muse in supporting an artist who is currently seeking to feed her muse through the Interdisciplinary Arts MA Program at Columbia College.

What You Get

For a limited time only, you can purchase artwork from Chicago artist, Monica J. Brown at a 20-30% discount -- from personal greeting cards, to limited edition lithographs, to original paintings.

Simply, click the "Gallery" tab near the the top of the page to view the artwork for sale. Once you've decided on a piece, scroll down on the right side of the Gallery page to find the price for your piece, then click on "CLAIM THIS PERK" to be directed to the PayPal/credit card checkout page. To indicate which piece you'd like to purchase, write the title in "Step 5: Comment” box. Include your address in "Step 3" for FREE shipping of your newly purchased piece!

The Impact

"After having been a practicing artist for many years, I began to feel that I needed to add some new tools to my toolbox in order to expand and grow. Thinking about earning a Master’s degree, I began researching graduate programs. I found a perfect fit with the program at Columbia which combined many of the creative ways that I express myself  (visual art, movement, and writing) with some of the ways that I’d wanted to learn to express myself (sound art and performance.)

I am honored to have been accepted into this program, and have successfully completed half of this 30hr MA degree program (at a part-time schedule) and am requesting your help in funding the second half. The total amount needed in tuition and fees is $12,000. I have secured all but $8000 of this amount. Art purchased through this campaign is for direct funding of tuition. All donations appreciated!"

Other Ways You Can Help

If you like the artwork, feel free to share this campaign with others.

Check out my personal blog here: www.mymyriadmuse.wordpress.com

Visit my website here: www.monicajbrown.net

story:
Update!!!  I am so happy to announce that I have reached my goal! Thank you so much for all of your support. There are still over 30 days in my campaign so any additional contributions would be incredibly appreciated as I have other transportation costs and materials to cover. The dye that I plan to use in my home studio alone costs $400 because it is pure, not synthetic.

THANK YOU ONCE AGAIN!!! And I look forward to sharing this with you!

Hi!  Thank you so much for taking a moment to check out my project!

I have been invited to participate in a Japanese textile workshop this fall in Fujino, Japan and am now raising funds to help cover the cost of the program.

For a long time now my background in the arts has continued to develop and expand.  More accustomed to paints and ink, my interest in textiles has only more recently come to take a prominent role in my work.  While in Bulgaria earlier this year, I studied traditional weaving on ancient Bulgarian looms.  My studies there were both fruitful and rigorous, and ultimately catapulted me into a profound love of traditional textile arts. 

                                       

                                           
                                       Rug and bag I wove while in Bulgaria

I am now hoping to expand that passion to the beautiful and ancient textile traditions imbedded deep within the fabric of Japanese culture and history.  Ultimately this workshop will function as the next step in what I consider to be the next phase of my work.  It will allow me not only the chance to expand upon my background in weaving, but introduce me formally to shibori dyeing techniques and silk thread-making.  I plan to use the knowledge and tools I acquire in Japan to inform the next directions I take creatively. 

                       Indigo dye vat and examples of different shibori techniques

To learn more about the workshop itself, please visit the Japanese Textile Workshop’s website here: http://japanesetextileworkshops.blogspot.com/

Budget: Workshop tuition (includes food, housing, and materials):  $2,500 USD

I can’t begin to express how important this is to me and the extent of my gratitude for your time and support.  I am truly appreciative and look forward to sharing my experiences with you.  Please check out my perks as my way of thanking you and inviting you to take home a handmade piece of the beautiful Japanese art of shibori!

Love,

Lauren

story:
(Deutsche Version siehe weiter unten)


ART AND THE WORLD FAMOUS TACHELES NEED YOU!



We are all fighting for the preservation and the maintenance of the independent and open Arthouse Tacheles in Berlin Mitte. Help us to save and develop this one of a kind international production and exhibition space for contemporary art of all genres.

When we talk about us, we mean the team around Linda Cerna, Barbara Fragogna and Martin Reiter plus, above all, a large number of artists and supporters, who are connected to the arthouse.

Tacheles is, since 22 years, the independent and open ground for contemporary art in Berlin. Visitors can witness the processes of art production, see experimentation and independent innovation far off the art market in direct contact and exchange with the artists.

Since many years a private investor as well as HSH Northbank have been trying to kick the artists out of the house to shut Tacheles down. The artists were forced to bear a lot of calamities: The water was turned off, walls and fences were built around the house, exhibitions were broken into and pieces of art were destroyed. Eventually, in March 2012, 50 guards of a private security firm tried to occupy the house to close it down for the artists and the public. But by decision of Berlin court the artists could return to the house after three days of peaceful demonstration and endurance in front of the building. The doors were open again!

Despite of all circumstances and despite of all the illegal actions against the artists we will not stop to secure the site of Arthouse Tacheles as a open, public and international production location of contemporary art. We will not allow private investors` interest combined with the inactivity of politicians to irretrievably destroy the self-organized art and culture project. This project was built by thousands of artists in the last 22 years and draws about 500.000 visitors each year from all over the world.

On June 20 2012, another negotiation on eviction was being held at Berlin County Court, and this could mean the final shutdown of the house.

And this is what we have to prevent in the last minute. This is the reason why the Foundation Tacheles which is standing in the course of formation, has to act as buyer of the building in Berlin Mitte. Due to an expert valuation of county court we need 3.580.000 EUR or $4398855 in order to do that.

– And thus we need your help!

Many well-known artists are willing to provide their work for the crowdfunding campaign so that the supporters will not only make a major contribution to save the house but also can get an original work of art in return.

We are not talking about less than the protection of the freedom of art and the necessity of open and accessible locations of art and culture in our societies worldwide. Support the Arthouse Tacheles, donate and spread this appeal…

Tacheles Foundation stands for:

1. Keeping, protecting and developing the Arthouse Tacheles / Berlin as a self-managed center to produce and present contemporary art works. As a think tank for the integration of new technologies to art, as well their social and cultural implications. As an international venue for the free theater and the dance scene.

2. Management of exhibitions and symposiums, promoting artistic and cultural exchanges at an international level. Establishing the Tachele school, organizing exchange projects in an international teaching and scientific framework.

3. Supporting contemporary art and technological development, researching and processing the social impacts of the cultural industry and technology in a parliamentary/democratic consumer society.


———————————————————-

DIE KUNST UND DAS WELTBERÜHMTE TACHELES BRAUCHEN DICH!

Wir kämpfen gemeinsam um den Erhalt des gemeinnützigen offenen Kunsthauses Tacheles in Berlin Mitte. Helft mit, diesen einzigartigen internationalen Produktions- und Präsentationsort für zeitgenössische Kunst aller Sparten zu sichern und weiterzuentwickeln.

Wir, das ist das Organisationsteam um Linda Cerna, Barbara Fragogna und Martin Reiter sowie vor allem eine große Zahl von Künstlern und Unterstützern, die im und um das Kunsthaus Tacheles angesiedelt sind.

Das Tacheles ist seit mehr als 22 Jahren der Freiraum für zeitgenössische Kunst in Berlin. Besucher können im Tacheles die Prozesse der Kunstproduktion, Experimentelles und freie Innovation jenseits des Kunstmarktes erleben und direkt in Kontakt und Austausch mit den Künstlern treten.

Seit vielen Jahren versucht ein privater Investor sowie die HSH Nordbank die Künstler aus dem Haus zu treiben und das Tacheles zu schließen. Die Künstler haben viel aushalten müssen: das Wasser wurde abgestellt, Mauern und Zäune wurden um das Kunsthaus gezogen, Ausstellungen wurden aufgebrochen und Kunstwerke zerstört, schließlich hatte man im März 2012 sogar versucht, das Haus mit über 50 privaten Security-Männern zu besetzen und für die Öffentlichkeit zu schließen. Doch mit Hilfe der Berliner Gerichte konnten die Künstler nach drei Tagen in das Kunsthaus zurückkehren und die Türen wieder öffnen.

Trotz dieser Umstände und trotz der vielen illegalen Aktionen gegen die Künstler lassen wir uns nicht davon abringen, die Zukunft des Kunsthauses als öffentlichen internationalen Ort der zeitgenössischen Kunst zu sichern. Wir werden nicht zulassen, dass private Investoreninteressen und die Untätigkeit der Politik das selbstorganisierte Kulturprojekt unwiederbringlich zerstören, an dessen Entwicklung in den letzten 22 Jahren tausende von Künstlern beteiligt waren und das jährlich über 500.000 Besucher aus aller Welt anzieht.

Am 20. Juni 2012 fand eine weitere Räumungsverhandlung vor dem Berliner Landgericht statt, diese könnte die endgültige Schließung des Tacheles bedeuten.

Und genau das gilt es in letzter Minute zu verhindern. Darum will und muss die in Gründung befindliche Tacheles Stiftung als Käufer des Gebäudes in Berlin Mitte auftreten. Dazu brauchen wir laut Wertegutachten des Landgerichts 3.580.000 Euro oder 4.398.855 US-Dollar.

Und dazu brauchen wir Eure Hilfe!

Viele namhafte Künstler werden im Zuge dieser Crowdfunding-Kampagne ihre Arbeiten zur Verfügung stellen, sodass die Spender nicht nur einen wesentlichen Beitrag zum Erhalt des Kunsthauses Tacheles leisten, sondern auch originale Kunstwerke erhalten können.

Es geht um nichts Geringeres als um die Freiheit der Kunst und um die Notwendigkeit von öffentlichen Kunst- und Kulturstandorten in unserer Welt. Unterstützt die Tacheles Stiftung, spendet und verbreitet diesen Aufruf…

Die Tacheles Stiftung steht für

* Erhalt, Sicherung und Ausbau des Kunsthauses Tacheles/Berlin als selbstverwalteter Produktions- und Präsentationsort der zeitgenössischen Kunst und Denkfabrik für neue Technologien und Kulturtechniken, insbesondere Städtebau und Stadtplanung, sowie ihre sozialen und kulturellen Implikationen. Tacheles als Spielort für die freie Theater- und Tanztheaterszene und ihre internationalen Netzwerke.

* Durchführung von Ausstellungen, Symposien, Kunst- und Kulturaustauschprojekten auf internationaler Ebene, Gründung der Tachelesschule, Austauschprojekte ihm Rahmen des internationalen Lehr- und Wissensschaftsbetriebes.

* Förderung von zeitgenössischer Kunst aller Sparten und Technolgieentwicklung, Erforschung und Aufarbeitung der sozialen Auswirkungen einer kulturindustriell und Technologie geprägten paralamentarisch/demokratischen Konsumgesellschaft.

story:
Hello World,

 My name is Angela Jaramillo and I am an artist from the San Francisco Bay area, however due to my current adventure in life I am currently in the beautiful desert of Thermal, CA. In mid-2011 I decided to leave my job in the retail and mortgage industry to persue my dreams of being an artist and photographer. I realized life was too short to do what I thought others had expected of me instead of doing what I expected of myself. I asked myself many questions all to come to the same conclusion, that yes, I do beleive I can be successful and feel fulfilled in life by solely doing the things that I love and that continuously inspire me. Shortly after realizing this my whole world shifted. I went from off and on sadness and negativity to living a life that was beyond positive. The people that I started to attract were like minded and very inspirational. I started to share my work without fear and found people loved it and wanted to be a part of it. Co-workers, family and friends started to purchase my work and I found myself in my first Art show in San Francisco. This was all so unreal, I never knew what an impact shifting your frame of mind could have on life.

 From the start of focusing on my art I never wanted to use the excuse of not having the ideal tools to keep me from trying, or any excuse for that matter. I take photos with a canon powershot S5is (far from professsional) and paint with whatever materials I can get my hands on. I am finding now, that I am reaching a new milestone of growth in my journey and need help to take my next leap. I am running into situations and jobs were my tools are no longer of my best interest to use. I am finally in need of a professional camera and more art materials. This is what brings me to my campaign, "A Time to Grow". I am reaching out to ask for the support to help me take this next leap. This is important to me because although I feel you can make do with what you have a persons creations can be limitless with the proper tools. A new camera would allow me to take my photography to the next level providing incredible images. More art supplies will allow me to create without limitations. My goal is to eventually reach a point in my career where I can travel, inspire, and help others through donating a percentage of my profit.

  I am in need of $2,000. $1,300, will get me the camera I need to take my photography to the next level and $560 will allow me to purchase enough supplies to create a larger inventory of work. And of course the rest of the funds will go back to indiegogo for allowing me to run this campaign. If I do not reach my goal the funds will still go towards whatever supplies I can get to continue growth.

 If you would like to see my work you can visit www.angelajaramillo.com or visit me on facebook at Angela Jaramillo Art and Photography. I greatly thank you in advance for taking the time to read about my campaign and considering donating.

I ask that you please pass this along and share with your friends and family.

 

Thanks a million!

 

~Anji :)

story:
My Story

My name is Zak Walters & I started Sky City when I was 15 years old in Buffalo, NY. Since then I have been published in national magazines, front page news articles, blogs from around the world and I have created a following of over 5,000+ people (Classy Kids). Sky City Clothing is not just a clothing line, it is a social network and movement. On our website you can create your own profile, your own online store, earn points to win cool stuff and much more. My dream is to see Sky City as an international brand promoting creativity, following your dreams, innovation, and of course staying classy. Like everyone else in the world, I want to make a difference. But instead of sitting around saying that and following the norms of society; I'm actually going to take a stand and do something about it. I thought the best way to do this would be with a clothing line, as it creates a community and brings people together through artwork & fashion. I worked my entire High School career and rather than buying a car or going shopping, I put every penny and all of my heart and soul into starting my own business. Now it's on its way to the top, but I just need that push to get there.     #ambition


The Impact

Eventually once Sky City is on it's feet and in stores around the world, I'm going to use the community I have and funding I earn to fuel a whole empire of new projects I have in mind:

  • Creating a hangout place for kids that allows them to unveil their creativity to the world through music and art.
  • An entrepreneurship movement that engages everyone to innovate, create new ideas for the world, and making it a better place. This program will fund ideas that we investigate and see that they come true.
  • Nurture other small businesses created by teens and young adults from around the world.
  • & Much, much more.

If I don't get the funding needed, I'm not giving up. This is MY dream and I think too many people lose faith in themselves and end up not doing what they want in life. I'm not letting that happen me, or any of the other people's lives that I affect in the process and result of this movement.


What I Need & What You Get

The homepage on our site is going to be the place you receive highest recognition for helping contribute. With every tier of perks, you or your business will receive a designated spot for an image on our homepage, that you can choose to be click-able to your website. Tickets for the raffle are good for all 12 months.


$1 - Entry into the Sky City raffle. Winners receive a free T-Shirt (drawn once a month for 12 months).


$10 - 50x50 Pixel Image on our front page.

       - Entry into the Sky City raffle.


$20 - 75x75 Pixel Image on our front page.

       - Entry into the Sky City raffle.

       - Name printed on limited edition 2012 contribution shirt


$50 - 100x100 Pixel Image on our front page

       - Entry into the Sky City raffle.

       - Name printed on limited edition 2012 contribution shirt

       - Receive (1) limited edition 2012 contribution shirt 


$100 - 125x125 Pixel Image on our front page

         - Entry into the Sky City raffle.

         - Name printed on limited edition 2012 contribution shirt

         - Receive (1) limited edition 2012 contribution shirt

         - Your own webpage in the 'Sponsors' section of our website

          (This includes a link, about me, picture and more for you or your business!)


$250 - 175x175 Pixel Image on our front page

         - Entry into the Sky City raffle.

         - Name printed on limited edition 2012 contribution shirt

         - Receive (1) limited edition 2012 contribution shirt

         - Your own webpage in the 'Sponsors' section of our website

          (This includes a link, about me, picture and more for you or your business!)

         - Receive (1) CUSTOM Sky City Shirt or Hoodie with your name printed on the back


$500 - 250x250 Pixel Image on our front page

         - Entry into the Sky City raffle.

         - Name printed on limited edition 2012 contribution shirt

         - Receive (1) limited edition 2012 contribution shirt

         - Your own webpage in the 'Sponsors' section of our website

          (This includes a link, about me, picture and more for you or your business!)

         - Receive (1) CUSTOM Sky City Shirt or Hoodie with your name printed on the back

         - Receive any 3 items in the store for free

         - Mention on all tangible(Magazines, Billboards) advertisement that Sky City purchases

         - If we produce a commercial, your name will be mentioned


The money fund raised is going to be used to give Sky City a voice.

  • Apparel Design & Manufacturing (Estimated: $3,000-$5,000+)
  • Hosting epic events that people can go to an express themselves ($5,000+)
  • Sponsoring aspiring athletes, musicians, and artists with similar dreams ($2,000+)
  • Sky City Commercial? ($10,000+)
  • Advertising in magazines, social networking sites, etc. ($10,000+)
  • Our own facility? ($25,000+)


Other Ways You Can Help

Honestly, tell others. I understand not everyone has the money to contribute and I don't expect it, but don't be lazy like the rest of America! Try and make a difference in the world. Share the movement. If you can't donate, maybe there is someone else you know who can!

story:
Short Summary

Two emerging curators from Wisconsin, Sarah Anne Stolte and Katie Apsey, are raising funds to assist with organziation of the exhibition "Air, Land, Seed" opening in Venice, Italy during the vernissage of the Venice Biennale.

This exhibition will address global tensions between home and exile, drawing from the unique perspectives of Indigenous peoples of Native North America. Six contemporary artists engaging in the politicized mediums of printmaking and multi-media will produce works that question the displacement and diasporas that define our collective contemporary existence. This reappropriation of colonial markers - flags, boats and airwaves - subverts the control and militarization of Indigenous homelands. Through participatory live print actions, performance, exhibition, and dialogue, our exhibition will repurpose such potent icons.

The exhibition will be presented at The University of Venice Ca’ Foscari during the Vernissage of the Venice Biennale (May 29 to June 2, 2013) and will travel to 516 Arts, Albuquerque, New Mexico (June 29 to September 21, 2013)

Curated by a collaborative group of artists, art educators, and curators, this project is the seventh Indigenous exhibition at the Venice Biennale (1999-2011) and the fifth collaborative event with the University of Venice.

Curators include: Elisabetta Frasca, Nancy Marie Mithlo, Paul Baker Prindle and Sarah Anne Stolte

The following artists' works will be exhibited in Venice:

Henry Payer http://www.tumblr.com/tagged/university-ofwisconsin?before=1316208906

C. Maxx Stevens http://cuart.colorado.edu/people/faculty/c-maxx-stevens/

Emily Arthur http://www.emilyarthur.org/

Dyani White Hawk http://dyaniwhitehawk.com/Dyani_Reynolds-White_Hawk/Home.html

Faisal Abdu'Allah http://www.arts.wisc.edu/artsinstitute/IAR/faisal/

John Hitchcock https://mywebspace.wisc.edu/jhitchcock/hybrid/hitchcock.html

Duane Slick http://www.duaneslickstudios.com/

Marwin Begaye http://www.ou.edu/content/finearts/art_arthistory/programs/Bachelor_of_Fine_Art_in_Art/studio_art/marwin_begaye.html

 

For more information please visit:

http://www.nancymariemithlo.com/

 

For more information on the 2011 exhibition, please visit:  

http://hybridpress.blogspot.com/2011/05/epicentro-re-tracing-plains-venice.html

 

For more information on the Venice Biennale, see:

http://www.labiennale.org/en/Home.html

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $1,500. Whether we meet our goal, surpass our goal, or do not meet our goal,  the money raised in this campaign will be available to our team and will assist with artwork shipping, travel, and per diem expenses. 

We have very unique donation perks! We activley engage with a group of supportive and creative artists in Madison, WI who are eager to see us travel to Venice and participate with this significant Contemporary Art event. We received multiple art donations that serve as "perks" or "thank yous" for donating. Your support will aid in sending two, emerging professionals to Venice for a politically charged and Internationally relavant art exhibition and you will become the proud owner of an original art work.

We thank the following artists for their generous donations:

---Balthazar: http://callmebalthazar.com/

---Mary Jane Connor: http://www.galleryninetynine.com/#!gallery

---John Hitchcock: http://hybridpress.blogspot.com/

---Sam Johnson: http://sdjart.tumblr.com/

---Sara Meredith: http://www.etsy.com/people/smeretactics?ref=pr_profile

---Paul Smith: http://www.facebook.com/pasdraws

---Matthew Stolte: http://www.freewebs.com/matthewstolte/

 

The Impact

This event will give two emerging arts professionals an opportunity to participate with a global event that would otherwise be economically out of reach. Furthermore, this exhibition will increase visibility of Indigenous arts that are often marginalized by the Contemporary Art world.

Additionally, we will share promotional materials of each donating artist during the Biennale, offering them international exposure.
 
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can't help:

*Help get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!

*Check out the Wisconsin-based artists who have donated works for our campaign by looking at their websites and visiting one of their upcoming shows in Wisconsin.

story:
I'm Jendella, a twenty-four year old photographer and filmmaker based in London. Alongside commissions and client work I work on socially-focused documentary projects about issues relevant to my community. I've previously worked on a project about ex-gang members in South London called Where The Devil Won't Go which has been exhibited around London including the Bernie Grant Art Centre in Tottenham, and also created a conceptual project about skin bleaching called Our Skin, which has been exhibited at the Arden & Anstruther gallery in Sussex and the Brockton Collective in Toronto, Canada. My most recent project is Young Motherhood, and it addresses the realities being a young mother raising children in Britain.

About Young Motherhood

I was inspired to start this project as I have friends who have had children at what society often deems to be "too young". I have witnessed their efforts in raising their children as well as working towards their own personal goals and have been inspired by their diligence and focus, as well as their persistence in overcoming challenges they face. However, in the mainstream consciousness this picture of the hard-working young mother is absent, and often the conversation about "teen pregnancy" or young motherhood revolves around "irresponsible" young girls, who are seen as promiscuous or opportunistic – opening their legs for council flats and handouts from the government. You will find "irresponsible" mothers at any age, but the tiny percentage of younger mothers who may not be making good decisions for them or their children has been used time and again to shame and belittle entire generations of young women playing one of the most important roles in our society. Not only is this ridiculous stereotype unfair, but the widespread public perception affects the real lives of young women who are working tirelessly to raise their children well, as well as continue in their education, career or other goals. This sensationalist perspective sells papers but it also misinforms policy makers and MPs, with young mothers being blamed for everything from the welfare deficit and housing shortage to urban crime and all other societal ills.

Unlike common documentary photographic practices I do not wish to co-opt the stories of the "marginalised" or "disadvantaged". The most important part of this project was travelling around the UK to photograph and interview women (27 in total) who are, or have been, young mothers – that is women who have given birth to children in their early twenties or below – to hear directly from them what their experiences have been raising their children. I see myself as using my skills to amplify their voices in the hopes that their experiences can intelligently inform discussion and start a much-needed conversation within our communities on how best to support young families in our common goal for an inclusive and healthy society.

What's Next?

So now that I've got all these interviews and images what am I going to do with them? Well, there are three important ways that I want Young a Motherhood to be delivered:

  • A film containing the interviews
  • A book of the photographs and interview transcripts
  • An exhibition of the portraits to launch the project and screen the film to the public in September or October 2014

The film and the book would be valuable resources for young mothers and those working with them. Many of the women I spoke to related how important it is to have community and the encouragement of others who really understood their situation, and for those young women who may be feeling isolated these resources are valuable.

The exhibition is an opportunity to get press interested in the project and I am planning to invite down MPs, policy makers, journalists and organisations to honestly engage in the discussion. The exhibition would also be an opportunity to host panels, events and activities for families to come down and engage in the exhibition, opening up the gallery space to the wider community.

How Much Is Needed?

Gallery hire for a week-long exhibition: £1,300

Producing exhibition prints and materials for hanging: £550

Promotional material for the exhibition (flyers, posters, invites): £150

As you can see the amount raised does not include the initial print run for the books as this is really expensive and would push up the total significantly! I am still researching my options for this (if you have any suggestions please get in touch!) but my initial plan is to take preorders in order to get the first set of books printed and take it from there.

What Do You Get?

For all your generous donations there are some perks provided ranging from love letters to invites to the exhibition private view and launch, to digital copies of the film and book and professional portrait shoot options (UK only). I'm working on providing more perks as well so I'll let you know when new ones become available! (Delivery dates for the digital love and love note perks are weekly, while rest will be delivered in Autumn, around the time of the exhibition launch. The portrait sessions will be arranged at a mutually convenient time for the both of us around Autumn/Winter 2014.)

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help me out by publicising the project and also this campaign with your family, friends, colleagues and any relevant organisations! If you are UK-based as well, please contact your local MP and let them know about this project and that you care about the misrepresentation of young mothers in the mainstream media. Click here to see how you can contact them, as well as a template email you can sign and send.

Finally, if you have any questions please get in touch by email (jeni@jendella.co.uk) or Twitter (@YMotherhood_UK or@JENDELLA), and use the buttons below to share away!

story:
I require a pair of reverse knee stilts from Digilegs (http://www.digilegs.com/) to create a fully realized Minotaur-type creature for an upcoming dark creative photoshoot. I have all of the other elements required, except for this aspect. I could create the creature without the legs however adding this item will help this project deliver a more powerful impact and believable character. 

What I Need & What You Get

I am looking to raise $1,200 to cover the legs and shipping to my studio. The cost will actually exceed this, as I will also be purchasing surface pieces, but require the framework foremost.

  • Donations of $25 will receive a signed mini print (5x7") from the shoot signed by the creative team.
  • Donations of $50 will receive a five minute Skype session with the photographer and model 
  • If I don't reach my fundraising goal, all available donations will go toward to the purchase of the legs and I will cover the rest. The photoshoot will not be cancelled.

The Impact

My portfolio focuses on and celebrates the male form. This project continues with that theme and injects a bit of magic into our world. A departure from the uninspired and mundane. Help make my vision a reality!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, I completely understand, but you can still help:

  • Share this campaign with like-minded friends who are interested in fantasy and the unusual. Make some noise!

story:
Stanley Andrew Jackson III

      I am a rising Junior Theatre Arts major with a concentration in Acting at Howard University. I was born and raised in New Orleans, Louisiana but I currently reside in Houston, Texas. During my freshman year of high school in Houston, I found the love my life. Art. In high school is where I first built my love for acting. I can always recall my sophomore year in high school after our production of Before It Hits Home, leaving the stage with the feeling of not being able to do anything else with my life. 

     I am now a student in the Theatre Arts department at Howard University. Since arrival at Howard, I can honestly say that my development and love for my craft has skyrocketed to levels I never thought possible. As I move toward my Junior year, I am hunger for more knowledge! Below, for your review is a link to my production shots over the past year at Howard Univeristy.

http://gallery.ediphoto.com/focus/stanley+jacks...

 

     I have recently been given the opportunity to train with Stella Adler Studio of Acting this summer in New York City. Stella Adler is a school that has trained thousands of actors to go on in careers in theater and film. The Stella Adler Studios advocates an essential focus in American actor training.

  • Stella Adler believes:

The need of a young actor to act is stronger than an intelligent nonprofessional can comprehend. The world may think that an actor’s ambition is focused on an appetite for money, success, and fame. Even those actors who admit to these aims tell only part of the story. The theatre is different from most other professions because it requires its dedicated practitioners to struggle toward a brutally honest, creative way of life.

  • The summer intensive is a 10 week program where I will have the liberty of taking classes such as: Adler Technique, Improvisation, Scene Study, Shakespeare, Movement, and Voice & Speech, Master Classes in Character and Acting for Film & Television are given to supplement the training.
  • Please help me to attend this program. As a growing actor, I believe attending this summer intensive will enhance the skills that I am currently gaining at Howard.

I charge you to donate $100, if that's not possible any donation will benefit.

Thanks for taking the time to even consider.

Stanley A. Jackson III

story:
Fotofringe 2015 is coming

  • My name is Jon Pountney, and I am a photographer living and working in South Wales. For the last 5 years I have been working on a project called Cardiff before Cardiff http://cardiffbeforecardiff.tumblr.com/ which explores ideas of community, history, and memory through film documentary photography. Whilst CBC is my best known work, I have undertaken several other projects, including one for the centenary of the Park and Dare Theatre, in Treorchy   https://www.facebook.com/Treorchy100Treorci, and a documentary on photography in the Valleys for BBC Wales.
  •  Fotofringe 2013 was held as part of 'Art In The Warehouse' in May of that year, in three different settings, and funded by myself. Giving over 20 photographers exposure in an unconventional and stimulating way, we used established galleries, pub skittle alleys, and our warehouse. Interaction with the community was key, and many people who would not want to visit a gallery enjoyed seeing the work in this way. Fotofringe 2014 was crowdfunded, and that £800 allowed us to do three large shows throughout the year, which took place in CardiffMADE, the warehouse, and in The Abacus.
  • This year we plan more, with the main part of Fotofringe happening under the umbrella of Made in Roath http://madeinroath.com in October. We are really excited to join the MiR family, because besides being lovely people, this will allow us to reach a greater audience, and utilise a greater number of exciting and unusual locations.    

Funding 

Funding this year will allow us to achieve more- more artists, more work, better promotion. We are creating a responsive, intuitive festival, commissioning new work, and creating ways for the community to see the magic of true photography. This kind of festival is unique in Cardiff, and is not meant to be stuffy, formal, or academic. Have a look and see what we did last year-http://fotofringe.tumblr.com/

story:
THIS IS WHAT WE'RE UP TO

In May of 2015, Taylor Yocom and KT Hawbaker-Krohn will bring together their two photography series under the fabulous roof of Public Space One. This gallery will exhibit Yocom and Hawbaker-Krohn's combined efforts under the name "Looker," a reappropriation of harmful, anti-woman slang that gives the gaze and perspective back to feminists. 

Yocom's project, "Guarded," unites gendered vulnerabilities, defenses, and notions of self-advocacy by featuring a community of women posing with their keys, mace, and other forms of "keychain self-defense." Inspired by her conversations with other women students at the University of Iowa, Yocom hopes that this photo series unveils the common realities that women face as they walk home from class and work. This series explores the diverse levels of violence and safety that feminine identities face within the Iowa City community.  Guarded has gained local and national press, and you can read more about the project at these links on Bustle and Little Village.

Hawbaker-Krohn's project, "Nudes Leaked," addresses issues of nudity and power. By teaming up with photographer Laurie Haag, Hawbaker-Krohn sought to give the women in her community an opportunity to demonstrate what nakedness meant to them as individuals and to flesh out (sometimes literally) the distinction between birthday- and power-suits. By inviting subjects to choose locations and poses that met at the intersections of their own strength and vulnerability, "Nudes Leaked" seeks to interrupt the cultural narrative that equates female nudity with weakness, mainstream pornography, and fear. 

WANNA HELP? 

In order to print and frame the portraits displayed at this upcoming exhibit, Yocom and Hawbaker-Krohn would like raise $1500 to cover these costs. The organizers will also be creating media such as buttons and posters to advertise this exhibition and to share at the community forum taking place at the opening night soiree at PS1. 

WHAT EXACTLY WILL THIS DO FOR THE WORLD?

The act of coming together and sharing our realities is an inherently feminist act. Both of these projects provide women from rich walks of life to tell their stories and to directly address the restrictions, inhibitions, and limits culture creates. By supporting this project, you are making a choice to support feminist artwork and alternative storytelling. 

On anther note, all additional proceeds will be donated directly to Girls Rock! Iowa City, a summer camp that prepares elementary-aged girls to engage with feminism through art, music, and creative discourse. 

WANNA BE A SPECIAL HELPER? 

Be sure to pass on this link via Facebook and your other social media platforms. For more information contact KT Hawbaker-Krohn via kthawbaker@gmail.com or Taylor Yocom at taylor.yocom@gmail.com
story_txt:
THIS IS WHAT WE'RE UP TO
In May of 2015, Taylor Yocom and KT
Hawbaker-Krohn will bring together their two photography series under the
fabulous roof of Public Space One. This gallery will exhibit Yocom and
Hawbaker-Krohn's combined efforts under the name "Looker," a
reappropriation of harmful, anti-woman slang that gives the gaze and
perspective back to feminists. 
Yocom's
project, "Guarded," unites gendered vulnerabilities, defenses, and
notions of self-advocacy by featuring a community of women posing with their
keys, mace, and other forms of "keychain self-defense." Inspired by
her conversations with other women students at the University of Iowa, Yocom
hopes that this photo series unveils the common realities that women face as
they walk home from class and work. This series explores the diverse levels of
violence and safety that feminine identities face within the Iowa City community.  Guarded has gained local and national press, and you can read more about the project at these links on Bustle and Little Village.
Hawbaker-Krohn's
project, "Nudes Leaked," addresses issues of nudity and power. By
teaming up with photographer Laurie Haag, Hawbaker-Krohn sought to give the
women in her community an opportunity to demonstrate what nakedness meant to
them as individuals and to flesh out (sometimes literally) the distinction
between birthday- and power-suits. By inviting subjects to choose locations and
poses that met at the intersections of their own strength and vulnerability,
"Nudes Leaked" seeks to interrupt the cultural narrative that equates
female nudity with weakness, mainstream pornography, and fear. 
WANNA
HELP? 
In order to
print and frame the portraits displayed at this upcoming exhibit, Yocom and
Hawbaker-Krohn would like raise $1500 to cover these costs. The organizers will
also be creating media such as buttons and posters to advertise this exhibition
and to share at the community forum taking place at the opening night soiree at
PS1. 
WHAT EXACTLY WILL THIS DO FOR THE
WORLD?
The act of
coming together and sharing our realities is an inherently feminist act. Both
of these projects provide women from rich walks of life to tell their stories
and to directly address the restrictions, inhibitions, and limits culture
creates. By supporting this project, you are making a choice to support
feminist artwork and alternative storytelling. 
On anther note,
all additional proceeds will be donated directly to Girls Rock! Iowa City, a
summer camp that prepares elementary-aged girls to engage with feminism through
art, music, and creative discourse. 
WANNA BE A
SPECIAL HELPER? 
Be sure to pass on this link via
Facebook and your other social media platforms. For more information contact KT
Hawbaker-Krohn via kthawbaker@gmail.com or Taylor Yocom at taylor.yocom@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

Hello, I'm Teresa Flowers, a multimedia artist using Indiegogo as a platform to raise money to fund the final realization of my Echoes Exhibit. This is my second round of fundraising for this project. I am happy to say that I was able to fund my initial work on Echoes last year using Kickstarter and I hope to have the same success this time around with Indiegogo.

This project of three years is deeply important to me because it explores my spirituality and beliefs. It is my hope this project, which explores the human capacity for multiple etherial and spiritual lives, will inspire and enhance the lives of others. I'm exited to finish and share this interactive installation art experience with all my supporters and the greater community.

The Vision


What We Need & What You Get

$10,000 funding for:

Purchasing Glass

Layering Materials for each light box

Installation of each Piece

Developing Photographs

Inks for printing

Transparency papers for printing and painting layers

Glass photography processing

Multimedia support of making the project 

Final delivery cost of each piece

Projected costs to make one piece (of 10) in approximately $1,500


Perk $12

Perk $25

Perk $55

Perk $75

Perk $150

Perk $200

11x17 Archival Inkjet Limited Edition Print

Perk $350 

Perk $500 -- Lunch date and signed book. 

Teresa Flowers Hard Back Photography Book: 

http://www.blurb.com/b/2952282-teresa-flowers-photography

Perk $1000 -- Producers credit, behind the scenes access to a fine art photo shoot, signed book.


    The Impact

    I'm an artist with over 125 paintings and 650 edited photographs. I have 16 years of experience with over 900 successfull photoshoots under my belt and 64 gallery showings throughout the world. I am driven to get the last $10,000 of funding of my overall goal of $20,000 project, and with $10,000 raised so far I am that much closer to accomplishing my goals and pushing the boundaries of contemporary art! I want desperatly for YOU to be a part of this. Its not very often we find outlets in the world for supporting cutting edge artists and its important for all of us to help out when and where we can. Help me share this page!

story:
٩(๑❛ワ❛๑)و Short Summary ٩(๑❛ワ❛๑)و

My name is Breagh Lunn, I am a circus artist from Nova Scotia, Canada. I now live in the beautiful city of Quebec. I have a background in Music, gymnastics, (and climbing trees). I have trained circus for 8 years now, performing Cerceau, Hula Hoop, and fire. I have trained and worked with some great coaches, and companies such as Cirque du Soleil, and RedBull. 

For this crowd funding project, I want to be completely transparent. I work full time at a restaurant as a barmaid, hostess, as well as part time at a cafe, coaching circus, so i can work full time as well on my circus career. You could call it a 'starving artist' lifestyle. 

I have the opportunity to buy a new and not well known apparatus, that would help me break out into the market. Due to living costs and training costs, I am not able to swing it on my own. This is where i need YOUR help. 

The apparatus is an Aerial Half sphere, or Aerial Half bubble (pictured above). In my eyes, it is very important to keep fresh and new, inventive, in the circus world. I worked with a company that debuted this on an international stage, and they have kindly offered to sell me this equipment.

I have worked my butt off both physically and mentally to be where i am today, as is the case with most of us in the in the circus world, and wouldn't give it up for anything. I love what i do, i love our community, and i love my work. That being said, I would not be where I am right now, without the support of friends and family, and people i have met along the way who have expressed their support and guidance. 

Your support will help me realize my personal goals in my artistic and professional career. Any little bit helps! Thank you!! 

٩(⸝⸝⸝◕ั ௰ ◕ั⸝⸝⸝ )و What I Need & What You Get ୧( ⁼̴̶̤̀ω⁼̴̶̤́ )૭

Heres the deal:

- I will need 900$ to be able to afford the equipment. (not including transport costs)
- I will have some sweet perks for helping me through this adventure! 
        -Hugs
        -Thank you videos
        -Thank you package!
        -Videos of me using the apparatus! Yay!
- Ideally, i would like to raise the 900$ completely, but will pay the rest of what i am not able to fund. 

 (◍•ᴗ•◍)♡ ✧*Other Ways You Can Help (｡・‧̫・｡).*＊♡

If you cant contribute - which i totally understand! - the best way to help is to SHARE! Facebook, twitter, all of those fun social medias that we love so dearly. Getting the word out is essential for success. 

THANK YOU GUYS I LOVE YOU!
If you have any questions, my email is breagh@breaghfox.com

✧٩(•́⌄•́๑)و ✧

www.breaghfox.com

story:
First a little history...

Burners, virgins, air-born and land-born: Welcome to Black Rock City Municipal Airport. You already know about Burning Man, but you may not know that the City boasts an active airport for it's 70,000 residents and is the second busiest airport in the state of Nevada during the festival. First opened in 1999 and designated by the FAA as 88NV, it is inside the Reno MOA on aeronautical charts.

Assisting 88NV since its inception has been The Black Rock Travel Agency (BRTA), the airport theme camp of record--BRTA has been the fixed base operation (FBO) of choice for the BRC Municipal Airport since the beginning. We are passionate about large art in public spaces, and assisting our world-class airport in any way we can.

When you think airport, you probably envision a terminal of some sort to host pilots, passengers and airport staff – at the very least, a structure as a gathering area for the operation.

Over the years, these airport structures were utilitarian, functional, and whimsical, but then the bar was raised. In 2006 one of our pilots, Twilight + crew, created what was to become the central focus of the airport. The "Terminal" as it was known, was bigger and bluer than anything we had seen. It was also heavy and difficult to assemble and store--its life eventually gave out and the materials were re-purposed after three great years.

After the 2008 event it was clear we would need a bigger space that was easier to construct.  It was then that Michael Twing, Steve Ramseur and others created an efficient, resourceful, economic and larger structure that would get us through the next four years. Ultimately, this structure carried us through to 2013 when we launched a design competition for the next incarnation of airport space.

The design of Starport...


Designed by architect Ross Smith, Starport won the worldwide design competition initiated by Luke Lukoskie (more on the competition here) for our new pavilion last year. Starport will be in a new class of architecture, one that is consistent with Burning Man being one of the largest outdoor art festivals in the world.

Starport is not your typical airport pavilion. It is a place where large-scale visual art is performed, community flourishes, and the desert pulses beneath an iconic structure with soaring shade wings and trusses.

A key feature of Starport is the Observation Deck, which will offer panoramic views of the city and runway. 

Starport is designed around a simple truss pyramid, which is economical, sturdy, easy to assemble, disassemble and store, and will last many years. 

Think of Starport as consisting of two main structural elements: one is the central truss (described above) and the other is a set of cables that tie the trusses to the ground and offer attachment points for the large shade sails. 

Starport is perfectly suited for Burning Man. It is easy to store, durable, functional, and fun. Most importantly, it will be an event space for all that Burning Man has to offer. Please join us in this endeavor and make Starport your next destination. 

Your donation will directly contribute to creating Starport: fully functional, long-lasting, elegant, and gorgeous. It is a timeless structure in the middle of nowhere, telling our artistic community at Burning Man, "You Are Home".

We have received incredible support from our extended airport community over the years but it’s time to take things to the next level…

To realize Starport's future, will require a total of $40,000 in our fundraising push: $10,000 has been slated from a variety of sources, so now we turn to Indiegogo for the remaining $30,000. 


To really kick things off we now turn to you, our loyal airport community, to keep the momentum flowing.

Here's a closer look at how the money raised from this Indiegogo campaign will be spent.



In return for your individual donation, a bounty of acknowledgements and decorations will be yours, in addition to the ongoing rewarding benefits of being a member of the Burning Man BRC Municipal Airport Community.

Just as we did with the terminal in 2009, the many BRTA volunteers who are dedicated to the Black Rock City Municipal Airport’s success will construct Starport.

We are committed to being transparent and thorough in reporting our expenses during this process.


Black Rock Travel Agency is excited to contribute an art installation, breaking new ground for large public structures at Burning Man.

Starport will host a variety of events that will be sure to attract interest from the community and create a new and a significant destination and meeting place for all.


If you didn't catch it earlier, we'd like to offer you a perk for your contribution. Check them out on the upper right of this page.  Any amount you can donate is appreciated! 

____________________________________________________________________

About Us


Michael Twing, also humbly known as Rebar King, has been a fixture at the airport since its inception in 1999. He has been instrumental in the organization and growth of 88NV, instigating many a riot with the other managers. Growing up in San Francisco with the likes of Jerry James (designed and built the first Man) and the Cacophony Society, he is no amateur to a beach burn. Rebar has been in the official position as the airports Logistics Manager, aka Land Commander, from 2006 to 2012. Now back at the reins of the Black Rock Travel Agency, Rebar knows how to get 'er done. Rebar is a general contractor by trade with a giving heart. When not out on the big dusty he's living large in Mill Valley, CA, with Suzanne, three kids and a doggy. 



Michael P. Anderson, aka Agent Nation, co-founded The Black Rock Travel Agency with Dream11 and Meshugganah in 1995, and has participated at Burning Man every year since 1991. It was an easy decision in 1999 to have the agency partner with the new airport:--Nation and a dedicated crew of travel agents have been active at 88NV ever since, where many agents have held management positions over the years. One of Nation's significant contributions includes BeRTA, one of the first Art Cars brought to the event, beginning in 1996. Nation and the BRTA have also supported the airports' annual pancake breakfast and Saturday cocktail party since their inception. Nation is active in his small town, Nevada City, CA, supporting many businesses with his professional IT services company. When not busy with his many sons (we've lost count) coaching Little League, volunteering with local schools, and river monitoring with SYRCL, he can be found soaking in the many hot springs of his favorite getaway - Soldier Meadows and the Black Rock Desert. 

Ross Smith is an architect, art enthusiast, and the designer of Starport Pavilion. After winning the BRTA/EcoLogic Design Labs sponsored design competition he soon realized it was up to him to see his vision manifest. He's been practicing architecture for two decades and believes the design process is all encompassing, from the initial concept to the tiniest bolt. New to the airport but no stranger to getting his hands dirty, he is excited to join the BRTA family in building Starport. He spent much of his childhood living in Guatemala and flying a Cessna with his dad. He now lives in Berkeley where he teaches and practices architecture. 

Steve Ramseur, known on the playa as Fabar, brought a humble yet effective shade structure and a modest but functional interactive art piece to the airport in 2002. The first little porch swing didn't appear until the next year, but over time, the shades and swings became the art projects. The Mood Swing made its debut at the airport in 2006, and after several remodels was accepted for display on the playa in 2010. The Pea Pod airport camp shade debuted in '09, and like Fabar, continues to serve the airport logistics crew. Back at reality camp in Eugene, Oregon, he has worked as an educator in construction and currently manages property. He is active in neighborhood and community politics, produces a mean homemade ginger ale, and once flew a hang glider 43 miles.
____________________________________________________________________

Spread the word: add our campaign to all of your social networks and Like our Facebook page. You can also use the Indiegogo share tools available on this below.

Black Rock Travel Agency Facebook Page

Also check out the Black Rock Travel Agency Website. 

Black Rock Travel Agency Website 

Burning Man Pilots: share this with your crew!


FUNDING OPTIONS

* Use your Credit Card

* Use Paypal

* Send a check to: Black Rock Travel Agency, 13310 Nevada City Ave., Grass Valley, California  95945

story:
Andes won an art contest!!!!

 

The prize is two round-trip tickets anywhere the Alaska Railroad goes. He will get to see his artwork hanging in the train depots all over Alaska! Help get Adrian and Andes to the Land of the Midnight Sun so that Andes can have the best 6-year-old birthday ever!!
story_txt:
Andes won an art contest!!!!
 
The prize is two round-trip tickets anywhere the Alaska Railroad goes. He will get to see his artwork hanging in the train depots all over Alaska! Help get Adrian and Andes to the Land of the Midnight Sun so that Andes can have the best 6-year-old birthday ever!!

story:
A Free Local Magazine

Hi there! Niche here. I'm a Bethlehem artist and writer creating a space for people to share their talents, gifts, and stories with the people of the Lehigh Valley. I really want this thing to be free. In order to do that, I need to raise a few bucks for printing. 

Even if no one contributes, I will still pay for as many copies as I can manage. The more money I can raise, the more copies I can print and distribute. 

The Cost of Printing

The money I raise here will go directly towards the cost of printing. I put a rough goal of $1000 because then I would be able to print the minimum amount of copies to distribute around the Lehigh Valley. But any amount is helpful and ALL will go towards printing copies and nothing else. 

What is the point?

The purpose of this mag is to share the stories of people and places and things that might not usually get the spotlight.

Thank You

Of course, if you contribute, you will get a copy of the magazine. If you can't give monetarily, you can definitely contribute by sharing a link or promoting the magazine and I would be very grateful.
story_txt:
A Free Local Magazine Hi there! Niche here. I'm a Bethlehem artist and writer creating a space for people to share their talents, gifts, and stories with the people of the Lehigh Valley. I really want this thing to be free. In order to do that, I need to raise a few bucks for printing. 
Even if no one contributes, I will still pay for as many copies as I can manage. The more money I can raise, the more copies I can print and distribute.    The Cost of Printing The money I raise here will go directly towards the cost of printing. I put a rough goal of $1000 because then I would be able to print the minimum amount of copies to distribute around the Lehigh Valley. But any amount is helpful and ALL will go towards printing copies and nothing else. 
    What is the point? The purpose of this mag is to share the stories of people and places and things that might not usually get the spotlight.
    
Thank You

 Of course, if you contribute, you will get a copy of the magazine. If you can't give monetarily, you can definitely contribute by sharing a link or promoting the magazine and I would be very grateful.

story:
Our Story

Over the summer, Brian and I are traveling across the United States to offer free workshops to help Native American youth find a creative voice. Focusing on teenagers, we are offering them expressive tools at a critical time in their development as well as showing them some of the many options that are available in the creative arts. It is widely recognized that the practice of art-making empowers, and our goal is to provide an introduction to the arts for the kids that we meet along the way.


The Impact

Our mission is to implement a systematic program for fostering individuality and self-expression in Native American teenagers, in order to empower them to break out of the perception that their options are limited.  And, to create a network for these kids so they can continue to explore the arts and make friends with other Native American teenagers around the country.


What We Need & What You Get

We’re going to be traveling light, and we want to send people most of the work generated while traveling.  We don’t want to be the lame, broke artists begging their richer, more successful high school friends for handouts, so we’re offering to sell the work that we are making on the trip as a way of funding our lean, mean, green adventure (that will hopefully be the only lame eco joke you’ll be forced to endure).  For now, we’re going to be living off of our own credit and praying that people like what we are doing.  The money that we raise will go towards our travel expenses (train tickets, food, etc.).

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word.  So far, we have contacts in New Mexico, Oklahoma, Texas, Minnesota, Wisconsin, and South Dakota, but we need more.  If anyone has contacts with Native Americans or reservations and would like to pass them along, we would be forever grateful.  You can also "like" us on Facebook, let your friends know that were going to be in their area (see google map for routes and dates), or just be cool.

story:
Donate $200 or more and receive PONCHO on Playa

What you get:

  • Beautiful custom designed PONCHO by artist and camp visionary Carlito Dalceggio
  • Delivered to you on the Playa were our dreams take flight

Any Donation Helps - Large or Small!

Thank you for your continued support of Caravan of Light

Caravan of Light - Who are We

CARAVAN OF LIGHT (COL) is an International Caravan of Burning Man Artists, Musicians, DJ’s, Healers, Writers, Philosophers, Filmmakers, Chefs, Community Tent Builders, etc… Coming together from many different Cultures to host and share an eclectic variety of art, music, cultural entertainment, sound healing, exploratory spirituality, impeccable cuisine, ALL served with genuine Hospitality… WE carry within US the Firey Spirit of Burning Man where we yearly pilgrimage to Black Rock Desert on a Magical Exile to the edge of the World…There, we climb back up the Spiral Seashell to the Origin. Caravan of Light Welcomes ALL!!!


“There exists on the Planet an Island that WE have ALL Created, a Secret Garden of the Soul where Everyone dives into New Myths in a Laboratory of Existence called CARAVAN OF LIGHT…” x Artist & Poet - Carlito Dalceggio

story:
Young New Yorkers is wavy for two main reasons:
 
1. ART INSTEAD OF JAIL FOR YOUNG PEOPLE LIKE US

Every young person makes mistakes, and every young person deserves a second chance.

Our program is an arts-based alternative to incarceration for teens being sentenced as adults. So far, more than 500 of us have avoided adult sentencing, and most of us have avoided a life-long adult criminal record at as young as 16 years old. Thanks to Young New Yorkers our adult criminal cases are dismissed and sealed.
 
2. ART ADVOCACY
We use art to advocate for ourselves. We take our artworks to court to show who we are beyond our rap sheets. To show the judges and prosecutors that we are awesome, creative and resilient young people who are working towards a bright future. This humanizes the way they see us, and humanizes the culture of the courtrooms, leading to better sentencing options for future teens.
 
We use art to advocate for criminal justice reform. At the end of each program we host a public art project that addresses a criminal justice issue that is important to us. We invite the very criminal justice professionals involved in our sentencing to attend our public art projects. So far we have used art to address mass incarceration, gun violence, solitary confinement, being prosecuted as an adult at 16, and local policing. We use art to re-center ourselves in the conversations on the issues that impact us the most.
 
Thank you for your partnership!

We are inviting you to contribute to the second part of Young New Yorkers – our public art exhibitions that allow us to advocate for ourselves, and to advocate for criminal justice reform.


Together we are to raise $10,000 to cover the next 6 months of exhibitions and create transformative justice!


Wavy!
 
Daniel (2012), Monasia (2013), Kimani (2013), Shawntiara (2014), Dejon (2017)

 
PS - THE BUDGET:
 
Art Advocacy
This covers the preparation of art testimony to take to court so that we may advocate for ourselves directly to the judge and prosecutors. The artworks, most often in the form of aspirational self-portraits, allow us to present who we are beyond our rap sheets in a visual way.
120+ court-mandated young people
$1,200
 
Annual 1-Day Program Exhibition
A public exhibition of our "best-of" aspirational self portraits from the 1-Day Arts Diversion Program.

200+ court-mandated young people
30+ criminal justice professionals
$2,400
 
8-Week Program Exhibition
We, the young people in this program, invite you and the very criminal justice professionals who sentenced us to Young New Yorkers to attend our December 5th exhibition on a criminal justice issue that is important to us.
15 court-mandated young people
30+ criminal justice professionals
30+ community members
$2,900
 
4-Week Program Exhibition
A public exhibition put on by the young people in YNY's next 4-Week Program in 2018. The public art installation will be designed by the next class of Young New Yorkers and will tackle a criminal justice issue of their choice.
15 court-mandated young people
30+ criminal justice professionals
30+ community members
$2,900


Video Production to Document Exhibitions
$600
