story:
About me:

Marko Zubak was born in 1979 in Zagreb, Croatia, in an artist surrounding, and started to create soon, playing in the family gallery on the island Rab. He starts studying painting at “Accademia delle belle arti di Bologna”, Italy in 1999. After three years of studying he has moved to Barcelona where he concluded his degree in “Facultad de Bellas Artes de Barcelona”, in 2006. In the same year he starts the course of multimedia in CIPSA school and finishes it in 2008.At the moment he is working and producing in his studios in Zagreb and Rovinj.

M.L.I.B.T.Y. project:

I started M.L.I.B.T.Y. project (My life is better than yours/ Don't worry, you don't live your life anyway), in 2009, as a small part of my global paper toy project.
My paper toys are usually free for download on my websites (Be sure to check them out, there are more than 200 toys, both customs and my design!). I come from traditional arts, but in 2007 I fell in love with paper toy art at a first sight. Since then, I'm active supporter to the paper toy community and have realized many paper toy projects, collaborations, solo and group exhibitions, artist in residency program, lectures, workshops and even stop motion videos. I'm also publishing the only paper toy mag on internet, II LOVE (www.yebomaycu.com), which is also free for download. More details on my websites and in my curriculum.

This year I started working on totally new paper toy character and some of the works are already available on my website for free download. I began with "Streetz Riot" series, under mentioned M.L.I.B.T.Y. project and this series will consist of more than twenty paper toys. Some of them will be free for download, some of them are downloadable under small fee and some are already available on my page.

Campaign:

My next step would be to make a big installation with the whole series. I have plans for other big series as well, but this depends on the success of this initiative. The idea is to make a big glass cube and construct the paper toy scene inside. As for now, it would be the biggest paper toy scene from one artist, considered as one unique work of art (and not different paper toys put together). The glass box will be 100x100x70cm and inside I'll make a scenography for some 20-30 toys. To have a better idea and a picture of my idea, check out the photos I took on the streets of Rovinj, a small city in Croatia, where I currently work on mentioned project, (amongst few others).

With this campaign I'm trying to raise some money for the material and production of the whole installation, which I'll expose on my future exhibitions.
Even if I don't reach my goal, I'll use this money to realize my idea. If there's any extra money, I'll channel it to the next paper toy scene installation, which will be also under the glass box with same dimensions and you can be sure to see a new campaign for it!
 
Note that if you buy one of my toys from my website, you'll also supporting the same project!

What's interesting here is that even if you just can't contribute, I have something for you and it's for free!! Just visit one of my websites and download any toy you like! Here are some tips to make it look like on my pics: use photo mate paper, 180 g and higher, precise cutter, inkjet printer, original cartridges (many inks fade under light with time), and set your printer settings to high quality printing.

Moreover, if you're creative and like collaborations, you can join one of my projects called "ye-boT initiative", customize one of my paper toys, @ www.yebomaycu.com, and take part in my future "ye-boT initiative" shows!

There's much more to say about my projects and achievements, but it would occupy too much space here, so if you want to know more, study my webpage or drop me a mail!

Marko Zubak

www.markozubak.com
www.yebomaycu.com
www.nextfloors.com

story:
THIRTY will kick-off Wednesday, March 6th @ 6pm in the Maryland Art Place galleries.

Maryland Art Place is excited to present THIRTY, a new professional development/mentorship program that focuses on public speaking and presentation for emerging artists. With your help, THIRTY will launch on March 6th, 2013!! Your support enables MAP to provide presentation materials and stipends for each of the selected, emerging artists. Please contribute at your comfort level. All contributions are appreciated, needed and meaningful to MAP and the participating artists

THIRTY: 30 Creative Minds Under 30 is a series of monthly talks featuring thirty emerging Baltimore artists under the age of thirty. All of the participants use a diverse range of creative practices, from visual art to performance, curatorial, community art, design, film, photography and technology to create visual experiences. Through these talks, guests will be able to learn about interdisciplinary practices and how these creative minds all share a similar goal: to present a visual experience.

THIRTY aims to connect emerging local talents with patrons of the arts. The series will engage guests through lively discussion on current contemporary art trends. It will also offer mentorship to the artists by establishing an inviting and casual environment for the artists, their guests and the public to network. These talks will be open to the artist community as well as the general local/regional community in an effort to support younger artists as they navigate ‘next steps’ in their careers.

Every month 2-3 artists will convene at Maryland Art Place (MAP) to present their perspectives on current cultural trends and how that plays into their practice, use of media and outcomes. Members of MAP’s Program Advisory Committee (PAC) will field critical response and at times, invite special guests for provide further mentorship and feedback to the participating artists.

The work done by the PAC has been an important component of the success of MAP's programming. The PAC consists of sixteen fine arts professionals and educators. The THIRTY committee consists of co-creator and 2012 student PAC member, Michelle Gomez and fellow PAC members Briony Evans Hynson and Joe Letourneau along with MAP Executive Director, Amy Cavanaugh Royce and Program Manager, Sofia Rutka.

THIRTY – One Wednesday a month @ MAP! Stay posted for exact dates.

Maryland Art Place (MAP) has served as an anchor for contemporary arts in Baltimore for over 30 years. MAP strives to inspire, support and encourage artists in this region by offering exhibition opportunities, workshop and mentorship programs. MAP creates a dynamic environment for artists to engage with the public, and each other, by nurturing and promoting new talents. MAP believes ‘THIRTY’ will bring an exciting and innovative new insight from artists to the community.

story:
Sweatervest Sweaterfest   |   Ithaca, NY   |   Sept 28-30

Visioneer David Danforth

I've been traveling across the country for 6 years.  Primarily, I've hitchiked all across this land.  In that time I've had no regular or reliable source of income, but I've learned a lot about how to live without money.  I've worked with Fat Kids Kitchen, a travelling free-food kitchen, since 2007.   I practice an economic style called Co-Operative Living.  Any time I want something, some sort of exchange is required to achieve my desired results.  Sometimes, that can be offering an opportunity for someone to give in a way they can feel good about.  Or an opportunity for someone to not give in a way they can feel about it.  We all do what we can, to live our lives and take care of our families.
 
I am creating a non-profit music and arts festival, Sweatervest Sweaterfest, for the benefit of a mobile free food kitchen.  The idea is if we can pay for most of the event up-front, any donations at the gate could go straight to the free food kitchen bus.
 
The idea is that there are people who like what we are doing, but can't come out to show their support.  So I wanted to create an easy way for people to contribute to the cause.
 
I've estimated that it will cost around $500 to provide porta-potties for our benefit.  Any amount closer to that goal is one less dollar I have to find somewhere else.  I know that our community would greatly appreciate having well maintained facilities at the first annual Interdisciplinary Arts Club meeting: Sweatervest Sweaterfest. 
 
You should also know that the Interdisciplinary Arts Club has an EIN# and can write tax deductible reciepts by request.

 

Co-operative Living

We need $500 for porta-johns.  That means if 5 people contribute 100 dollars, or if 500 people contribute a dollar, we'll have reached our goal.

Anyone who contributes $100 will recieve a shoulder or carrying bag.  Hand stitched by me, out of durable material, designed to take some wear and tear.  These type take around 7-12 hours to complete, and have custom features and patches.  They also come with a 1 year repair plan.  As long as you don't shred it to pieces or burn it completely to ash, I'll fix it.

  • $50 dollar donations will recieve 3 very nice custom patches, hand made by me.
  • If you send us $15 or more, I'll make you some kind of sweet patch, and mail it to you. 
  • Even if you can't contribute, I usually have a needle and floss on me, and I would do a quick on the spot repair for anyone.

 

Anything Helps :-)

 

The Impact

This project is the begining of so many beautiful friendships, and connections already.  Plans are already in motion for collaborative efforts next year.  The idea for the event is to get together as many different groups and types of people together.  Bringing them together, under something I think we all can agree upon.  Art is Good.  We don't all agree about what constitutes good art, but that's ok too.  The glbt community, the rainbow family, the grateful dead family, ravers, burners, christians, activists, mothers, and fathers all share something else in common.  We all value the freedom to live by what we belive in.  This is a celebration of diversity, and the many things that we the human family share in common.
 
In my travels I have descovered what it means to me to be a leader.  A leader is someone who does the most work, and therefore people expect them to know things and to tell them what to do.  I've worked with a free food kitchen for 5 years.  We go to gatherings all over the country, feeding and helping eachother, and everyone else.  I've built, by myself, a kitchen that fed a gathering ranging from 20 to 100 people over two weeks.  One or two volunteers usually find me when I'm preparing a big meal.  Or sometimes I'll ask, in general, if anyone wants to help me.  I've been to hundreds of festivals, dozens of Rainbow Gatherings in the national forest, and I've walked through just about every cool town in this country.  Through all of these experiences, I've been thinking for a while of how I might run an event, and appreciate when events include the "audience" as co-creators.
 
When you live on the road, and you want to have friends when you go back places, you have to do right by them.  I see people I know, everywhere I go, and if I want to have a pleasant existence it behooves me to be good to people.  I work hard, I dance hard, I sing crazy, and I help everyone I can, in whatever way I can.  In turn, I usually taken care of.  But I'll help you whether I like you or not, whether you take care of me or not, everyone gets fed, everyone gets water, and everyone gets a cigarette that asks, if I've got them.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't personally contribute, maybe you can help connect us with others who are sympathetic to our cause.  Feel free to share this in your social networks, forums, or mailing lists.

You should also know that the Interdisciplinary Arts Club has an EIN# and can write tax deductible reciepts by request.
 
Co-operative Living
We need $500 for porta-johns.  That means if 5 people contribute 100 dollars, or if 500 people contribute a dollar, we'll have reached our goal.
Anyone who contributes $100 will recieve a shoulder or carrying bag.  Hand stitched by me, out of durable material, designed to take some wear and tear.  These type take around 7-12 hours to complete, and have custom features and patches.  They also come with a 1 year repair plan.  As long as you don't shred it to pieces or burn it completely to ash, I'll fix it.

$50 dollar donations will recieve 3 very nice custom patches, hand made by me.
If you send us $15 or more, I'll make you some kind of sweet patch, and mail it to you. 
Even if you can't contribute, I usually have a needle and floss on me, and I would do a quick on the spot repair for anyone.
 
Anything Helps :-)
 

The Impact
This project is the begining of so many beautiful friendships, and connections already.  Plans are already in motion for collaborative efforts next year.  The idea for the event is to get together as many different groups and types of people together.  Bringing them together, under something I think we all can agree upon.  Art is Good.  We don't all agree about what constitutes good art, but that's ok too.  The glbt community, the rainbow family, the grateful dead family, ravers, burners, christians, activists, mothers, and fathers all share something else in common.  We all value the freedom to live by what we belive in.  This is a celebration of diversity, and the many things that we the human family share in common.
 
In my travels I have descovered what it means to me to be a leader.  A leader is someone who does the most work, and therefore people expect them to know things and to tell them what to do.  I've worked with a free food kitchen for 5 years.  We go to gatherings all over the country, feeding and helping eachother, and everyone else.  I've built, by myself, a kitchen that fed a gathering ranging from 20 to 100 people over two weeks.  One or two volunteers usually find me when I'm preparing a big meal.  Or sometimes I'll ask, in general, if anyone wants to help me.  I've been to hundreds of festivals, dozens of Rainbow Gatherings in the national forest, and I've walked through just about every cool town in this country.  Through all of these experiences, I've been thinking for a while of how I might run an event, and appreciate when events include the "audience" as co-creators.
 
When you live on the road, and you want to have friends when you go back places, you have to do right by them.  I see people I know, everywhere I go, and if I want to have a pleasant existence it behooves me to be good to people.  I work hard, I dance hard, I sing crazy, and I help everyone I can, in whatever way I can.  In turn, I usually taken care of.  But I'll help you whether I like you or not, whether you take care of me or not, everyone gets fed, everyone gets water, and everyone gets a cigarette that asks, if I've got them.
 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't personally contribute, maybe you can help connect us with others who are sympathetic to our cause.  Feel free to share this in your social networks, forums, or mailing lists.

story:
Project Summary

Walking a dog in the cold fall and winter weather in Montreal, Canada is the perfect testing ground for touchscreen gloves.  I bought my first pair of touchscreen gloves last Fall (2011). The first pair I ordered looked really cool, but they weren’t cheap. I paid a little more than $60, but figured they were a new, tech-gadget-type of product and figured that’s what they probably cost.

Aside from the sizing issue (I returned the first pair because they were too small), the gloves seemed pretty cool. I put them on and was able to answer a call. Well actually, I realized I couldn’t do much more than that after playing around for a few minutes. The gloves had these silver patches on the index finger and the thumb of both hands. The problem with the design, was that these patches didn’t conform to the tips of the fingers. When you think about it, that’s pretty much the same as any gloves. You don’t need them to fit snugly and tightly on your finger tips normally because you would take them off to perform any delicate tasks. I went back to the trusty Internet and ordered a few more pairs. This time I decided to buy gloves that were knit and made of acrylic. The acrylic gloves fit very well because of the spandex, but as the temperature went below 5C (40F), the gloves weren't keeping my hands warm. They did work really well and allowed me to text, type and do whatever I wanted, but the quality wasn’t always very high. Overall they were good but I definitely needed something that was warmer and of better quality. So I decided to try creating some touchscreen gloves with my friend Scott. Through my experience using the gloves and Scott's design skills, we were able to create Concepts Gloves™.

We see touchscreen gloves as a bridge between the static charge on your hands and your touchscreen device, not as regular gloves with special capabilities. Yes they are gloves and gloves should keep your hands warm, but the first priority and duty of touchscreen gloves is to enable you to text, touch and type with precision and accuracy. Gloves that fail in this regard fall between gloves and touchscreen gloves. In other words, they are pretty basic gloves with some small degree of touchscreen capability. So the deal is, if you live in a cold climate and you’d like to or you absolutely need to be able to keep your gloves on (like who wouldn’t) to use your touchscreen device, then remember this:

1. If touchscreen gloves don’t conform tightly and snugly to the tips of your fingers, they won’t work properly.
2. The thicker the glove, the worse they will work.
3. Silver patches on your finger tips make as much sense as a car with square wheels
4. One size fits all never fits all when it comes to touchscreen gloves.

We decided to make gloves for different seasons and different climates because there really couldn’t be one material suitable for all seasons and all climates.


What We Need & What You Get
We are looking to raise more capital in order to be able to market and build our brand and our business. Your funding will directly impact how far and wide we can reach and will also help us start on next year's designs and production as well as fund additional product development.


Fund this project and you'll get a pair of gloves within 10 days (or less). The gloves are perfect for any smartphone user or as a holiday gift. Depending on how much you contribute you can choose from 2 models in 2-3 different styles (depending on the model) which come in 2 sizes. We will provide you with a product catalogue upon receiving your funding. We will also contact you with a personal thank you note and/or call if you leave us your contact info.


Since this project is already rolling, any funds we get will help us keep things going forward. No matter what you contribute, you will have a direct impact on our success.


The Impact
Here's how we see the world: There are big corporations that do what they will with no regard for the environment, for the consumer or for anything other than profit. Small businesses like ours are the exact opposite. We care about the environment (we ship in 100% recycled and biodegradable envelopes), consumer (product was created with care and passion by touchscreen a device user) and tend to do business with small businesses (little boutiques, small online stores etc). At the end of the day this product solves a real world problem (not an important one, but one nonetheless) which is people avoiding having to take off their gloves in winter in order to be able to use their touchscreen. It's useful, well designed and created with care and passion by a one person company.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute money to this project, you can still help us by getting the word out about our product.
You can use the indiegogo share tools or you can get people to follow us on Twitter or Facebook. Every little thing you can do will ultimately help this business succeed and grow.

Thank you so much for your help and your belief. We care so much and promise we will succeed with your help!

Much Love,

Doug & Scott
Concepts Gloves™

Doug & ScottConcepts Gloves™

story:
Who

I've been taking photos ever since I was a kid, after winning a Polaroid camera in a painting competition. In the intervening years, a camera has always with me during important periods of my life, capturing whatever I was passionate about at the time: as a surfer it was surfing, and music; in art school it was arty stuff; as a spiritual seeker it was travels throughout India. Now, after years of working as a graphic designer, author and film journalist, I have realised what I enjoyed the most was taking photos. Living in London, it was live music that reawakened my love of looking at life through a lens, propelled by one of those twists of fate that comes from saying "I can do that" at the right time (which was also how I became an internationally published author), and I ended up shooting some gigs for a friend's website. From that moment I was hooked. 

There are many styles and genres of photography, but shooting live gigs presents many of its own challenges. The lighting and on-stage action is constantly changing, often extreme, and always unpredictable. OK, it's not exactly a combat zone, but there is no shortage of noise, projectiles and fervent behaviour, especially when you are caught in the mosh pit (more than once I've come out bruised). When it comes to capturing the emotion of music, a picture is definitely worth more than a thousand words.

“I really love the use of light in your music photographs. Even though there is a lot of energy and movement in them, they radiate an emotional stillness, which I think creates a very beautiful contrast.”

Catie Disabato: PR Account Executive, Los Angeles

Over the past couple of years I have been out at least twice a week, shooting hundreds of up-and-coming bands in small, mostly badly lit pubs and clubs, as well as more established acts in bigger, well-lit venues. Many of these acts have risen from local obscurity to national recognition, and others have inevitably fallen back into obscurity. 

“Love your photos! Beautiful shots.” 

Nicole: Vuvuvultures/Energy Snake Records

What

Following in the tradition of some of the great music photographers that came before, I managed to secure a position as a house photographer for a well-known London promoter. It is unpaid, but has allowed me access to some great gigs that I would have otherwise not had the opportunity to shoot. Unlike the halcyon days of the UK music press, opportunities, and the economics, for making any money from shooting gigs have become almost non existent. However, galleries, such as Proud, Getty and Rock Archive, have regular exhibitions of music photography. Of course, these are shots of music icons by renowned photographers and, for the most part, come with price tags to match the subject's and/or photographer's status. From my point of view, the main job of a music photographer is to take iconic pictures, and not just pictures of icons, and it should be remembered that many of those iconic photos in the galleries were taken before the artists became icons, which is what gives them their current value.

With that in mind, I approached the promoter with the idea of holding an exhibition, in one of their venues, of some of my best shots taken in their venues around London (look in the gallery section of this campaign for some examples, more will be added over the campaign). To my (pleasant) surprise, they agreed, which left me with the dilemma of not only choosing a selection of pictures to display but also getting them printed and framed. Narrowing the selection down to 30 images from the thousands I've taken is not going to be easy, but finding the money for the printing and framing is going to be harder, and this, dear friends, is where you come in.

“Chris has what one could call a musical eye, capturing bands in their perfect moments.”

Sirius Flatz, manager of Molotov Jukebox

I've been given this great opportunity to show off my work, which I hope will lead to more exposure and some paid commissions, but, unfortunately, I don't have the spare cash to pay for all the prints and frames. I've found a great printer and frames at a very reasonable prices, so I'm asking for your help to make the exhibition a reality. It will also be a chance for you to get prints at a greatly reduced price on what they will be offered for sale at the exhibition. Every image will be signed and numbered, with a maximum print run of 21 each. I am offering framed and unframed options. I will also be producing a 48-page printed full-colour booklet of the images at the exhibition, which will include a note of thanks to all the backers.

Even if you are not familiar with all the bands or artists, the images are strong enough to please any music fan looking for something special to hang on their wall. And in the unpredictable music world, it may even turn out to be an iconic shot of the future.

“Chris is a fantastically diverse photographer, not only has he managed to capture the madness on stage, his stills are just as epic.”

BLEECH

How

The exhibition is currently scheduled for January at Hoxton Square Bar & Kitchen in East London, although an exact date has to be fixed. The sooner I can raise the money, with your support, the sooner I can get the prints and frames made, and commence the exhibition.

I've made the perks as affordable as practically possible, but the more people that support the campaign the better, so please tell your music-loving friends. And any money raised here, beyond the goal, and once the perks have been fulfilled, will be donated to the Gig in a Gallery charity campaign. So an extra reason to support this endeavour.

See what The Londonist has to say about the campaign.

story:
Abstraks focuses on art and artists internationally that operate on the outskirts of the mainstream. Our main goal is to expose and promote all the talented artists that may have slipped under your radar. Our company does not limit its focus to any one style, influence or movement; we instead look to showcase any artist or group which possesses a powerful attitude and an interesting perspective. Abstraks is not only a magazine, but a community for expression. The Abstraks Mobile App is a tool that helps artists, art lovers, art galleries and organizations connect in a meaningful way. It allows users to find artists and venues in and around their community in a familiar and powerful way.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $9,500 dollars to develop the mobile app. If we are successful in reaching our goal, we would like to celebrate by throwing a launch party/gallery show for the mobile app! The unique perks that our supporters receive are limited edition prints and original artwork from artists we’ve featured, and Abstraks merchandise.

The Impact

  • Abstraks app users can create a profile where they can add and edit information and artwork. These profiles allow artists and art lovers alike to connect both in their community and all over the world.
  • Galleries and other creative organizations can also create profiles and reach out to their community in a new and innovative way.
  • The Abstraks news feed will mirror the information in our blog and also feature updates from the artists and galleries that you follow.
  • Follow events from their conception through to their realization. The updates will come directly from the planners of the event so you won’t miss out on any information.
  • “Favorite” anything that you want to come back to later. Individual posts, events, artwork, artists, galleries and organizations can all be bookmarked and revisited later.
  • The categories page helps the user zero in on a particular medium or genre of art. Find artists and galleries that work in the categories that you enjoy most. 
  • Check the calendar to find out what is happening on any given day. Openings, exhibits, open studios and more posted by all the people and places that you follow. 
  • The map offers a way to find events posted by people and places that you haven’t yet discovered. The map will display what is going on all around your current location anywhere in the world.

Risks & Challenges

Our first objective at Abstraks is keeping you in the loop. We enjoy finding and sharing the art that is happening all around us. But along the way, there may be some step backs and hurdles in creating this app. Regardless of obstacles to come, we plan to work through it with the mobile developer to make this app meet the user’s needs. We also plan to make additions to the app along the way that makes connecting with art more efficient.

Other Ways You Can Help

This app will be a platform for connecting our users and centralizing all the services that Abstraks has to offer right at your fingerprints. The Abstraks app at its most basic level is a tool that will help you explore and expand your community. You can help spread the work amongst your community about this campaign, and any one who would be interested and benefit! Be sure to check out www.abstraks.com and our social network pages, and use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you,

Abstraks Team

story:
The magic of feminine beauty.

Recent decades, with their rapid emancipation markedly changed our perception of female beauty. Perhaps we have lost a lot, starting to forget the ideals to which hundreds of years have sought the best artists of mankind.

In our project, we would like to show you what a woman saw Soviet artists of the last century. They embody painters heat of their hearts, the joy of life on earth.

Support our project and you will get a full color gift calendar that will delight you with a 2016.

story:
The Scoop:

Hey there, my name is April Elizabeth Henry. I am an artist and a full-time student residing in Augusta, Ga.


Studying abroad is something I've always seen myself doing, but unfortunately my bank account doesn't seem to have the same vision. This summer I hope to study Art History and Spanish in Spain. The Problem: I cannot afford this trip. At the end of the day, I can no longer accept this problem to hinder a once-in-a-life-time opportunity. The Solution: You.  


What I Need:

- My program fee is $5,530 (not including tuition). Fees are due March 1, 2015. For more specific information about my trip, click the link below:

http://www.gru.edu/studyabroad/salamanca.php

- Through scholarships (Helping Outstanding Pupils Educationally Scholarship,Benjamin A. Gilman International Scholarship, GRU Study Abroad Office Scholarship) and fundraisers (raffle tickets, Yankee Candle) I HOPE to raise a large portion of my program fee.

What You Get: Exciting Perks

  • $25 Backers: Shout your name into the universe as I thank you for your gracious heart
  • $50 Backers: Handwritten post-card from Spain to keep you up-to-date with my new adventures (yupp, I'll still shout your name into the universe maybe even in Spain?)
  • $75 Backers: Handwritten thank-you note including a wonderful selfie taken in front of a famous landmark in Spain (it'll look good on the fridge - everyone loves a selfie)  And...no worries I will still shout your name into the universe.
  • $100 Backers: 5x7 print of an original piece of artwork I will create while inspired by the places I will visit in Spain (Madrid, Segovia, Toledo, Pamplona, Barcelona, Figueres) I will also shout your name into the universe as I thank you for your gracious heart.
  • $200-and-up Backers: 8x10 April Henry original acrylic painting on canvas I create while inspired by the places I will visit in Spain (Madrid, Segovia, Toledo, Pamplona, Barcelona, Figueres) Yes, I will still shout your name into the universe as I thank you for your gracious heart but this time it will be on top of a building at the top of my lungs.

FOR A PEAK AT MY WORK: https://www.facebook.com/april.e.henry.1/media_set?set=a.1623482625861.84551.1200358258&type=3


In All Honesty...

I plan to send off all perks two weeks after I return home from my trip (August 1, 2015). I am asking for your patience if any of life's wonderful setbacks delays this process. I will do my best, of course, to get your perks delivered in a timely fashion.


Other Ways You Can Help:

If you cannot contribute, then I am asking you to share this link to any social media website or app. The more my story is exposed the better! Thank you in advance for taking the time to share my campaign. Also, you can use the Indie share tool.
story_txt:
The Scoop:

Hey there, my name is
April Elizabeth Henry. I am an artist and a full-time student residing in
Augusta, Ga. 



Studying abroad is something I've
always seen myself doing, but unfortunately my bank account doesn't seem to
have the same vision. This summer I hope to study Art History and Spanish in
Spain. The Problem: I cannot afford this trip. At the end of the day, I can no
longer accept this problem to hinder a once-in-a-life-time opportunity. The
Solution: You.   

  What I Need:

- My program fee is $5,530 (not including tuition). Fees are due March 1, 2015. For more specific information about my trip, click the link below: 
http://www.gru.edu/studyabroad/salamanca.php 
- Through scholarships (Helping Outstanding Pupils Educationally Scholarship,Benjamin A. Gilman International Scholarship, GRU Study Abroad Office Scholarship) and fundraisers (raffle tickets, Yankee Candle) I HOPE to raise a large portion of my program fee.

  What You Get: Exciting Perks
 

$25 Backers: Shout your name into the universe as I thank you for your gracious heart
$50 Backers: Handwritten post-card from Spain to keep you up-to-date with my new adventures (yupp, I'll still shout your name into the universe maybe even in Spain?)

$75 Backers: Handwritten thank-you note including a wonderful selfie taken in front of a famous landmark in Spain (it'll look good on the fridge - everyone loves a selfie)  And...no worries I will still shout your name into the universe.
$100 Backers: 5x7 print of an original piece of artwork I will create while inspired by the places I will visit in Spain (Madrid, Segovia, Toledo, Pamplona, Barcelona, Figueres) I will also shout your name into the universe as I thank you for your gracious heart.

$200-and-up Backers: 8x10 April Henry original acrylic painting on canvas I create while inspired by the places I will visit in Spain  (Madrid, Segovia, Toledo, Pamplona, Barcelona, Figueres) Yes, I will still shout your name into the universe as I thank you for your gracious heart but this time it will be on top of a building at the top of my lungs.


FOR A PEAK AT MY WORK: https://www.facebook.com/april.e.henry.1/media_set?set=a.1623482625861.84551.1200358258&type=3

In All Honesty...

story:
Carmagnole se produira cette année, le 1er Septembre 2012 sur le site extérieur de Mouton Village à Saint-Charles-sur-Richelieu et nous avons besoin de tous pour réaliser ce projet. La plateforme Indiegogo nous permet d’ouvrir cet évènement à un public plus large.

Vos dons nous sont nécessaires pour l’achat de matériaux de constructions qui nous permettront de réaliser : la scène, les coulisses, le bar, la cuisine, et des éléments de décor … Ces dons représentent un investissement à long terme puisque la majorité des structures mises en place cette année seront réutilisées pour les éditions suivantes.

Le carnaval CARMAGNOLE a été créé en 2001 sous l’impulsion de jeunes montréalais visionnaires et fonceurs issus du monde de la relève du cirque, des arts et du communautaire. L’objectif de cet organisme à but non lucratif est alors d’offrir une scène sans censure ni pression aux jeunes artistes des arts du cirque et ainsi leur permettre de s’échapper momentanément du cadre conventionnel de l’industrie artistique. À la manière du Carnaval traditionnel, Carmagnole est fondé sur la participation du public et de ses partenaires pour renouer avec les origines populaires de cette forme d’exploration et d’expression libre.

Le 1er septembre prochain, au grand plaisir de tous, le carnaval CARMAGNOLE revient après 6 années de long sommeil afin d’offrir la 6e édition de son évènement unique en son genre. Répondant à un réel besoin, le carnaval Carmagnole a su se tailler une place de choix dans le monde des arts carnavalesques et de la culture citoyenne. Épaulé dès le début par de fidèles collaborateurs, tels que le Cirque du Monde et la caserne 18-30, le carnaval CARMAGNOLE peut surtout compter depuis sa création sur la participation bénévole toujours croissante d’artistes de la relève et du monde professionnel, de gens de divers horizons et d’organisateurs passionnés. C’est un évènement populaire et festif accessible à tous, un espace d’échange interdisciplinaire et intergénérationnel.

Depuis ses débuts, le carnaval CARMAGNOLE est une fête solidaire qui n’existe que grâce à la précieuse collaboration de 725 bénévoles, 600 artistes et une trentaine de partenaires. C'est la raison pour laquelle, chaque année, nous comptons votre générosité pour continuer à offrir un évènement de qualité ouvert à tous. . 

Votre participation nous sera d’une grande aide pour le succès de cet évènement qui a du cœur au ventre et qui donne la chance à l’art et au grand public de se rencontrer dans un esprit de partage et de solidarité. En contrepartie de votre contribution financière, vous recevrez un présent original à la hauteur de votre investissement ( voir liste …).

Merci beaucoup pour votre aide précieuse et au plaisir de découvrir vos costumes pour le carnaval Carmagnole !

L’équipe Carmagnole !

story:
Short Summary

Rob Pruitt’s The Andy Monument was organized by Public Art Fund and was originally on view in Union Square, New York, March 30, 2011 – September 4, 2012; the exhibition was curated by Nicholas Baume, Director and Chief Curator, Public Art Fund.  The Contemporary Arts Museum Houston (CAMH) would like to showcase The Andy Monument at a new location - on our front lawn at the corner of Montrose and Bissonnet in the heart of the Museum District in Houston, TX. Andy Warhol was (is) an icon of pop culture, art and innovation. Rob Pruitt, a contemporary artist inspired by Warhol, created The Andy Monument as a tribute to the late artist. The sculpture is based on a combination of digital scanning of a live model and hand sculpting. Its surface is finished in chrome and the seven-foot-tall figure stands a top a concrete pedestal. It depicts Warhol as a ghostly, silver presence: a potent cultural force as both artist and self-created myth. 

What We Need & What You Get

The Contemporary Arts Museum Houston (CAMH) encourages public engagement and exists to be a leading destination to experience innovative art. CAMH is a non-collecting institution and bringing this monument all the way from NYC to Houston is not cheap. Here’s a break down of the estimated costs:

  • Loan fee for Rob Pruitt’s The Andy Monument from Public Art Fund - $12,000
  • Crating - $2,000
  • Delivery – $3,500
  • Return shipping – $3,500
  • Installation – $5,800
  • Crate storage -  $1,000
  • De-installation – $1000
  • Care and maintenance – $1,200
  • Insurance policy – $2,000
  • Your picture with Andy – priceless!

Total estimated costs: $32,000!

This is why we reach out to YOU to help fund this project and bring Andy to Houston. If everyone who visits The Andy Monument on CAMH’s lawn gives even a $10 donation, we can fund this project. 

What you get:

  • Help Houstonians and visitors from around the world meet the father of Pop Art, Andy Warhol. Be a part of history.
  • When Andy arrives, take your photo with The Andy Monument.
  • A printed commemorative sticker for your contribution – to be used however you wish.
  • Invitation to The Andy Monument ribbon cutting ceremony at CAMH and a free drink ticket at the event.
  • A one-year CAMH $75 Individual membership (for a list of membership benefits, click here.)
  • A one-year CAMH $100 Household membership (for a list of membership benefits, click here.)
  • A one-year CAMH $250 Friend membership (for a list of membership benefits, click here.)
  • An exhibition tour with Valerie Cassel Oliver, CAMH’s Senior Curator.
  • Dinner with CAMH’s Director, Bill Arning, an art world rock star in his own right!
  • CAMH is an IRS 501(c)(3) organization, so all contributions are tax deductible. 

The Impact

CAMH is a leading destination located in Houston, TX for contemporary art. Bringing The Andy Monument to the front lawn of the Contemporary Arts Museum Houston in the heart of the Museum District will bring a part of Andy’s legacy to Houstonians and visitors of all ages and backgrounds. As the sculpture became a landmark to the people of New York City, we hope the same will be true for Houstonians and its visitors. The impact Andy Warhol had on history is hard to measure but no doubt is relevant to our current culture. Andy’s presence will engage his visitors and open dialogue about his work and contemporary art. CAMH reaches audiences of over 150,000 each year and recently started a new initiative to use its lawn space as an outdoor exhibition area for sculptures, attracting and engaging visitors to the Museum and surrounding Museum District. 

Who was Andy Warhol?

Andy Warhol (1928-1987) was an American artist and is considered the quintessential Pop Artist celebrating fame, wealth and glamour and in so doing changed the course of both popular culture and art history - inspiring most artists who have risen to fame in the past 30 years in significant ways. In his larger-than-life persona, Warhol remains one of New York's enduring icons. Today his iconic images of the Campbell Soup Can, Elvis or Marilyn are so ubiquitous they appear safe, but it's not hard to remember how strange and downright dangerous these were when they were first hung in museums.

Who are we?

The Contemporary Arts Museum Houston is a non-collecting institution dedicated to presenting the best and most exciting international, national, and regional art.

Our mission: CAMH is a leading destination to experience innovative art. CAMH actively encourages public engagement with its exhibitions through its educational programs, publications, and online presences.

Our motto: ALWAYS FRESH, ALWAYS FREE

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word! Tell your friends, family - even strangers about bringing Andy to Houston.
  • Make sure you and your friends come visit Andy when he arrives and take your photo with The Andy Monument.
  • Post your photos with Andy to CAMH’s Facebook page, twitter page, or geotag and tag us through instagram at #camh.
  • Visit CAMH – we are ALWAYS FREE!

CAMH AND HOUSTON THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT OF THIS PROJECT! (We’d like to think Andy would thank you, too.)

We want to thank our friends at Public Art Fund for their wonderful support. 

 Rob Pruitt: The Andy Monument was organized by Public Art Fund, New York.

story:
Short Summary.

I'm not one for asking for help. I've never been very good at it. This is my attempt at that. In short I'm trying to create a vision of a better world through joy, laughter, and love. I am an artist and I reach people through my art. I'm asking for you to help fund that art and to help me transform this world.

What do I need from you? What do you get from me?

What I need is finances to create things. What you get besides my gratitude are my services. These are all things that I am good at and I expect you to be satisfied with. I'm going through indie go go because I think I can reach more people this way. I'd love your help and I offer my skills in return.

What I hope to see...

Is a world filled with more positivity. I make it a duty of myself to spread laughter and joy to all those around me on a daily basis. Right now I'm reaching those that I interact with on the day to day, but my true passion is to reach people I've never met. I want someone having a bad day to find something I've created and to help them have a better day. To know that there is someone out there that loves them or at the very least can make them laugh.

Other ways to help.

I know that not everyone that sees this is going to be enrolled in my vision. Or perhaps you're enrolled in so many visions that you can't help out financially right now. I get that. What I would ask instead then is for you to help me spread the word about this campaign. Every person that sees this is another potential donor. 

Thanks for the support. I truly couldn't do this without your help.

story:
Update: Do you remember the ubiquitous haze during Burning Man 2013? Also, the eerie and extraordinary red sunrises and looming flaming moons at night? As we now know, those photogenic phenomena were a direct result of one of the worst wildfires in California's history. It began at nearby Jawbone Ridge in the Stanislaus National Forest and spread to Yosemite National Park. Now called the 2013 Rim Fire, it burned 254,685 acres, or 400 square miles, of our protected woodlands. The Temple 2013 for Trees has reached our original goal of raising $5,000 in order to replenish more than DOUBLE the wood we used to construct the Temple of Whollyness in partnership with Green Forests Work. Since the Rim Fire devastation, our new goal is to raise $10,000 by September 30th so that we may also donate funds to the National Forest Foundation to aid with the Rim Fire restoration efforts. Please consider a donation to benefit our neighboring Black Rock Desert forest lands.

(Photo credit: Michael Holden)

The Temple of Whollyness’ purpose is to serve our community as the spiritual nexus -- to offer the space and opportunity for participants to express themselves in order to become whole. In that spirit, we are inaugurating a tree planting program to offset the wood we burn, so that these two opposite actions complete the circle of our Temple. We feel that we are being called to take this important step in the direction of walking-the-walk towards fully cherishing our planet. With the Temple 2013 burn, we will completely “Leave No Trace" in a way that extends beyond the pristine playa we leave behind.

 

15 year old growth forest from one of Green Forests Work's original test plots

 

By looking into the flames without fear, we see that we need carbon and fire to live as they are building blocks of our planet. In a very real and tangible way, fire promotes vegetation growth and the subsequent uptake of CO2 in natural ecosystems. Perhaps there is a way that fire can help us break the code on solving some of our environmental issues? Our Temple can honor the importance of the release of fire, while completing the cycle by re-planting what was burned.

A child helping plant tress in Appalachia

 

So we decided to ask tree experts for assistance with our plan and they calculated the number of replacement trees from converting the weight of the Temple birch, pine and fir into board feet. A board foot is a standard measure of the usable wood in a tree. You can picture a board foot as a piece of lumber one-inch thick, one foot wide, and one foot long (1" x 12" x 12"). The Temple uses about the same amount of wood as an average single family home. If we look at trees that are only 12" in diameter, that would be 800 trees. With adjustments for mortality at 12%, we were advised to re-plant about 907 trees. We set our goal to plant 2 trees for every tree that we use to build the Temple -- to not only replace the trees that will serve us in our Temple offering, but to return even more trees to our planet -- so we are planting 2,000 trees in total.

Green Forests Work

 

We chose Green Forests Work as an ideal organization to collaborate with. They are focused on regenerating forest lands in Appalachia that have been destroyed from hilltop removal for coal mining. Their mission is intriguing because of all the co-benefits their work creates: forest regeneration, biodiversity regeneration, water basin restoration, soil toxicity amelioration, social justice promotion, and climate change mitigation/adaptation, to name a few. The cost for Green Forests Work to replant these 2,000 trees is $4,500. We will net this amount, after Indiegogo fees, when we raise a total of $5,000.

Since we are a gathering of environmentally and socially concerned citizens, we hope to easily raise the required funds and gift Green Forests Work the TOTAL amount we receive from this Indiegogo campaign. 

Thank you for your support.
Wholly yours,
Temple 2013 for Trees

Green Forests Work teaching volunteers how to plant trees

 

Vista of re-planted forest lands in Appalachia

 

Boy Scout volunteers planting trees in the forest lands of Appalachia

Risks and challenges

We understand that some might say this approach is fire-washing and certainly this subject can be incendiary and much debated. Perhaps with the Temple 2013 burn, we can begin a dialogue about supporting a broader and borderless definition of “Leave No Trace.” This campaign is only one small step in what we believe is a positive evolution. In the end, this project is about planting 2,000 trees to help facilitate forest regeneration in Appalachia.

We chose Green Forests Work as an ideal organization to collaborate with. They are focused on regenerating forest lands in Appalachia that have been destroyed from hilltop removal for coal mining. Their mission is intriguing because of all the co-benefits their work creates: forest regeneration, biodiversity regeneration, water basin restoration, soil toxicity amelioration, social justice promotion, and climate change mitigation/adaptation, to name a few. The cost for Green Forests Work to replant these 2,000 trees is $4,500. We will net this amount, after Indiegogo fees, when we raise a total of $5,000.
Since we are a gathering of environmentally and socially concerned citizens, we hope to easily raise the required funds and gift Green Forests Work the TOTAL amount we receive from this Indiegogo campaign. 
Thank you for your support. Wholly yours,Temple 2013 for Trees
Green Forests Work teaching volunteers how to plant trees
 
Vista of re-planted forest lands in Appalachia

 
Boy Scout volunteers planting trees in the forest lands of Appalachia



Risks and challenges
We understand that some might say this approach is fire-washing and certainly this subject can be incendiary and much debated. Perhaps with the Temple 2013 burn, we can begin a dialogue about supporting a broader and borderless definition of “Leave No Trace.” This campaign is only one small step in what we believe is a positive evolution. In the end, this project is about planting 2,000 trees to help facilitate forest regeneration in Appalachia.

story:
Hello from the Sequential Artists Workshop, or SAW. A couple years ago we had the crazy idea to open a school; an informal, but serious school, with a curriculum to match any anywhere, but without the baggage, the loans or the politics of higher education. This was the challenge. To create an outpost of support and learning in the comics world.

 

We’re here to educate students and support artists. And we’re asking for your help to make this upcoming year as amazing as our past year.

 

View our entire history here: http://sequentialartistsworkshop.org/wordpress/about/our-history/

 


We’ve taught comics to youth, adults, newcomers, to visiting students, and to artists and writers in other fields. And we’re proud of the amazing education we’re offering to our current full-year students, who are getting an excellent, full-time, intensive education in drawing, writing, reading, applied media, experimental projects and all things sequential art.

 

You can see our success from our testimonials:

“I’d say I left SAW feeling like I got so much more than I expected or understood I would get. I got a deep, personally catered fine art education in the fundamentals that can push my own work and style forward.” - Jared Cullum, http://www.hausohubris.com/?p=390

Best workshop I have ever participated in, hands down. I learned as a writer, a cartoonist, and as a teacher. …If you have any chance to participate in any of the various workshops, classes, or year-long studies at the Sequential Artists Workshop, you must! Tom Hart and Leela Corman have something special going on down there – as good a workshop as I’ve ever been involved with. - Justin Colussy-Estes

Your school and curriculum are fantastic…I honestly feel far more capable of writing something worth reading after a few classes … Also, Justine being so harsh is perfect. She actually teaches and builds on ideas. – Mike K, Philladelphia

How I know a week at @comicsworkshop did its job: I wake up every morning unconcerned with email, burning to draw & write. – Deanna, NYC

Totally inspiring and a few of us left awe-struck… I feel like the big thing I got from SAW was an intense drawing focus, & feeling that I can just dive in and work on stuff at anytime. - Elvis 007

 

You can see more here: http://sequentialartistsworkshop.org/wordpress/about/testimonials/

 

We’ve hosted more than a dozen art shows and book releases, highlighting the work of great, often underexposed artists like Tom Galambos, Derek Ballard, Caroline Paquita, Justine Mara Andersen, Andre Frattino and more.

Here’s a run down of our list of shows and events: http://sequentialartistsworkshop.org/wordpress/category/events/

We’re building the connections that artists need to thrive. We fostering creativity and talent in our students, and we’re taking on the challenge of connecting our artists and students to the Gainesville community, and into the larger community of comics artists.

We applied for a State of Florida Humanities Grant to document some of Florida’s amazing histories and folklore and are researching further into making this book a reality.

We’ve given TWO grants to comics creators, Jess Ruliffsson and Julia Gfrörer, with plans for six more.

We earned grants from a local community organization to furnish SAW and from the City of Gainesville to support a local fan convention.

We partnered with the Department of Defense to create a comics portal for returning veterans.

We teamed up with Departments of the University of Florida as well as the Harn Art Musuem and the Florida Museum of Natural History.

We’re currently working with Jenny Zervakis and John Porcellino to publish an omnibus of Jenny’s Strange Growths.

 

HELP OUR MISSION TO SUPPORT AND NURTURE COMICS ARTISTS

To do this, we’re asking for your help. Donations, to keep our lights on, to pay our evil landlord (super evil!), to keep our Risograph running. Every donation matters and helps as does every click to help spread the word . No effort is too small.

Your donations are tax-deductible though Fractured Atlas (until our own 501(c)3 status is finalized.)

Many of our gifts are of limited or single quantity, so we are asking that you read the below, then visit our Etsy store to make your final choice. Put your specific requests in the comments field, or email us at thesaw@sequentialartistsworkshop.org 

We will be filing thank yous on a ROLLING BASIS so if you want something by Christmas or mailed to someone else, let us know and we will do it. We have outstanding interns waiting to package your prints and posters!

Gifts from Derek Ballard, John Porcellino, Vanessa Davis, Michael DeForge, Dash Shaw, Eleanor Davis and more!

Some benchmarks and rewards for you:

$10 will help us print some more postcards and fliers. For this you’ll receive the below 5 x 7 postcard by Michael DeForge.

 

$25 will go to our fund for more art supplies. For this, we’ll send you the above postcard plus any poster found on our Etsy store: http://www.etsy.com/shop/SAWSupportStore/

 

 

$50 will go to repairs to our ceiling fan, or getting that hole closed in the closet. Grab a postcard and take either the John P $50 print or Michael DeForge 11x17 print, or 2 $25 posters from: http://www.etsy.com/shop/SAWSupportStore/

 

$100 will go to utilities. We’ve got lots of single drawings on Etsy for you at that donation amount. http://www.etsy.com/shop/SAWSupportStore/  Or take two prints or 4 posters!

 

$200 pays our rent for two weeks! We have lots of original art at our Etsy store for this donation amount: http://www.etsy.com/shop/SAWSupportStore/

$500 will help get another artist down here to recharge in the warm air while teaching our students. Contact us about a funding gift or combine from the Etsy Store. 

$1000 will blow our minds, help support all the artists and students both here at SAW and beyond, thank you. What can we reward you with? Name it, let us know!

 

Our $7500 total is a lowball description of what we need, and aimed towards only keeping the doors open through 2013. The more we manage to raise, the more everyone wins, especially the students and visiting artists of SAW. So please, if you can donate to support quality education, affordable access to skills and resources that support artists and engage students.

Thank you!

———————–

POSTSCRIPT

To our previous benefactors from 2010, thank you for your support.

We received great donations of books from

  • Kate Correa and Lisa Schwartzburg
  • Phil Weiss
  • Derik Badman
  • Annie Koyama
  • Tim Kreider
  • Jed Alexander
  • Top Shelf
  • Lou Copeland
  • Dan Boyd
  • Wow Cool

Furniture and supply donations from

  • University of Florida SA+AH
  • Central Florida Office Plus
  • Bill Bryson
  • Joe Courter and The Civic Media Center
  • The Citizen’s Co-Op
  • Satchel’s Pizza
  • Chris Fillie
  • Tomis Aycok
  • Pete Mejija
  • Sam Manno

Art Donations from:

  • Vanessa Davis
  • Trevor Alixopulos
  • John Porcellino
  • Nick Abadzis
  • Jason Little
  • Nick Bertozzi
  • Sarah Glidden
  • Alex Jansen
  • Ed Kanerva
  • Dash Shaw
  • Megan Kelso
  • Steve Weissman
  • Sam Henderson
  • Josh Bayer
  • Jed Alexander
  • Eleanor Davis
  • Michael DeForge
  • Drew Weing
  • Tim Kreider


Are we probably forgetting YOUR in-kind donations from 2012? Please realize this is temporary, and we will remember your specific efforts to support us, bang our hands into our heads and say “duh!” Then we will update this page. Please know your donations and efforts have all been graciously appreciated by the staff and students here at SAW, thank you! Feel free to contact us about a receipt, since the end of the year is upon us and our non-profit status is imminent.

 

———————–

 

Thanks for your support, or order or whatever! Please know that you are ON THE SIDE OF GOOD.

 

Your donations are tax deductible! And you will help create the school by providing:
  • Desks, furniture, drawing boards, etc.
  • Rental space, utilities
  • Supplies (art, office)
  • Computers and software
  • Marketing and printing services
  • Tuition assistance for needy students
  • Artist support for visiting artists
  • Administrative support
  • Odds and ends like a Pantone book, tape binding/spiral binding machines, keeping our Risograph working, etcetera!

story:
My name is Roselina Hung, and I have been selected to take part in the SIM Residency in Reykjavik, Iceland for the month of September. I will be one of twelve artists creating and presenting new works and taking part in the Icelandic art scene with local and international artists. During my residency, I will be working on a series of large-scale drawings, Pretty Boys Kill Me, in preparation for an exhibition at Gallery Fukai in spring 2013 in Vancouver, Canada. 

SIM Residency Reykjavik

Run by the Association of Icelandic Visual Artists, the SIM Residency offers artists a living space and studio in Reykjavik. The building where I will be residing and working in also houses studios for about forty Icelandic artists, as well as an art school, workshop and exhibition space. As a self-directed residency, SIM seeks to promote a creative environment where artists can reflect, study and work on their artistic process. All expenses related to the residency, including a program fee and travel expenses, are paid by the artists.


Working on my first Pretty Boys Kill Me drawing in my Vancouver studio

How will this residency benefit me?

Last year, I had amazing opportunities to attend residencies at the acclaimed Banff Centre (Banff, AB) and Ox-Bow School of Art (Saugatuck, MI). After my Banff residency experience, I made it a goal for myself to attend an established American residency, followed by an international one. With your help, attending this residency will allow me to reach the personal goal that I set for myself last year, which means a great deal to me.  

As a working artist, I was fortunate enough to receive fellowships and scholarships for my residencies last year. The SIM Residency, in Iceland, however, is 100% self-funded. I believe in the importance of artist residencies, as the content and quality of my work is greatly inspired by new environments, people and ideas. It was during my Ox-Bow residency that I first came up with the idea for my Pretty Boys Kill Me drawings, which led to this residency and an upcoming exhibition at Gallery Fukai in Vancouver next spring.


Roselina Hung - so damn hard, coloured pencil on paper, 26"x36", 2012
My first finished drawing from this series.

Pretty Boys Kill Me

This project explores my interest in the act of looking and appropriation in relation to beauty, love and desire in popular culture while allowing me to continue my examination of portraiture and its place in contemporary art. I will be creating several 26x36 inch coloured pencil drawings of repeat patterns of pretty boys.  The images will be overlaid with text taken from personal e-mails, chats and texts, examining how words are used in communicating desire, wavering between lovingly sentimental and overtly sexual. This continues my investigation into both public and personal histories within my artwork.

I am interested in juxtaposing the text with images of these soft-featured men, who have been deified in contemporary culture and art history, as gods, angels and saints are often depicted as androgynous males. The hand drawn execution of the pattern work will teeter between being created lovingly, from a lover's point of view, and somewhat obsessively, not unlike an adolescent girl's fantasies. This project will focus on both process and final product. As the drawings will be labour intensive, I am interested in whether I am able to maintain the same level of obsessive detail or if my drawing capabilities will be affected, thereby alluding to the title of the project.

Your contributions

As all expenses related to the residency are paid by the artists, you will be helping me pay for:

  • Travel/airfare
  • Residency fee
  • Room & board
  • Living expenses (food)
  • Materials
  • Shipping work back to Vancouver

Every contribution helps, no matter how small, as I will still be paying for my studio/apartment/bills in Vancouver while I am away. I am taking unpaid leave from work to attend this residency, as it is too good an opportunity to pass up. Any extra funds raised over my goal will go towards preparations for my exhibition next year.

Some of the perks available as a thank you for your contribution (frames not included)

In return

For every contribution made, I will offer my artwork in return, from prints to postcards to original drawings and paintings. Through supporting my art practice, you will get art in return - a win-win situation!

The impact

I am a practicing artist who has been building my career, both within Canada and abroad, since I received my MA Fine Art in 2004. This residency will be a unique experience that will expand my connections to the international art scene, as I will present my work through an artist talk and exhibition in Reykjavik. It will provide me with uninterrupted studio time, opening up my practice to new concepts about art, therefore advancing my career. 

Other ways you can help

I understand that some of you may not be able to make monitary contributions, but you can still help by spreading the word about my project to your friends and family. Please show your support through sharing this on Facebook and Twitter.

My thanks

Thank you for reading about and supporting my project.

To see more of my artwork, please visit: www.roselinahung.com

For more information on the SIM Residency, please visit: www.sim.is/sim-res

story:
Making Pink Heart Art Possible

This will be my first year at Burning Man and I would love to help contribute to all of the amazing art on the playa. In order to do that I need your help :-)

My project is going to be a steel structure standing close to 20' high, it will be powder coated Pink, It will have pink LED lights on the down tubes from top to bottom, It will have LED lights inside the heart, And it will have propane flames coming from the 36" ring all the way around the heart!

I also plan on building a two person swing that will hang under it ♥

This project will be built in my home town of Bend, Oregon by myself "Joe Beal" and my father "Jack Beal"

Everyone that contributes $1 or more to this art project will get a big thank from the builderS "me and my dad" and a photo of the finished project on the playa at Burning man 2012, for your loving contribution you will also receive a pink sticker that says "I helped make an art project possible at Burning Man 2012"

All funds raised will go to materials to build the project, the perks you the contributers will recive, and any Indiegogo fees.

IF NOT FULLY FUNDED BY THE DUE DATE YOUR MONEY WILL BE FULLY REFUNDED

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

Send me a message to heyimjustjoe@gmail.com with ideas on what we should name the finished art structure! 

LOVE & (((HUGS))) Joe "insert playa name" Beal

story:
Hello!


Who we are

We are 15 students from the Rhode Island School of Design and Brown University taking a course this semester called 「Dialogue Across the Diaspora: Haiti, South Africa, Art, and Narratives of Resistance.」 

The course looks at art and stories created in historically catastrophic circumstances. Though they are very different countries with very different histories, both Haiti and South Africa were shaped by slavery and the ensuing racial discrimination.  


What We Are Doing

"Dialogue Across the Diaspora" literally enacts a dialogue between students at Rhode Island School of Design and Brown University and students at the University of Cape Town, South Africa. Our course is running in conjunction with a course Professor Anthony Bogues (Brown University) is teaching at the Centre for African Studies at the University of Cape Town (http://www.africanstudies.uct.ac.za). Together with the South African students we are conducting research in support of an exhibition that we all curate together called 「Ships of Bondage」, which will be put up at the Slave Lodge Museum in Cape Town, South Africa (http://www.iziko.org.za/museums/slave-lodge) in late November 2013. 

「Ships of Bondage」 will examine the global networks involved in the African slave trade, looking at the connections between Rhode Island, Haiti, and South Africa. It will tell the story of slave insurrections during the slave trade, exploring the struggle of the enslaved to resist captivity, gain freedom, and return to their homelands. 

This is an unprecedented opportunity for all of us and for the Slave Lodge museum, as this will be the first exhibit in South Africa to involve a comparative study of slavery and its legacies in North America , the Caribbean, and Africa.

But there's more and that's where you come in.


WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

We have the chance to go to Cape Town, South Africa, to meet the students at the University of Cape town, and together personally install the exhibition!

Your donation can make this happen for the entire class.

And since we are artists, we will send you a handcrafted thank you present. Maybe a watercolor of the Slave Lodge. Or a photograph of Table Mountain at dusk. It's all up to you!

To travel to South Africa and meet the students we have been collaborating with online, to see South Africa for ourselves, to go to Robben Island, and stand where Nelson Mandela and hundreds of other people were imprisoned for believing the color of one's skin should not be a bar to equality…

These would be life-changing opportunities for all of us.

So, if you can help us out, please do!! And we will say thank you in the best way we know how - by spreading gifts of knowledge, art, and creativity across the world!


What We Need & What's in it for You

After a generous donation from our school, this trip is looking to cost about $2000 per person - this includes airfare, meals, compensation to the University of Cape Town for housing us, etc. However, not everyone can afford to pay this much money in order to get there. Your donations will go towards making this trip an equal possibility for everyone in the class. 

We are hoping to raise enough money for the trip to be free for everyone, but any amount gets more of us closer to Cape Town! If our goal is not reached, we will use what generous donations we do receive to get as many students there as we can. 

GET EXCITED!

At RISD, we are artists from all across the board - some painters, some illustrators, textile artists, fashion designers, and film makers! But we all have enthusiastic creativity in common. In gratitude and to show our appreciation for your generous donations, we want to share some of our work with you!

Paintings, hand drawn post cards, photography - all are possibilities in a warm thank you from us to you. Plus, we will send you pictures of our new friends, the installation of the exhibition, cultural artifacts, and parts of Cape Town and anything else along the way. 


The Impact

Traveling abroad is a critical part of studying and living in our modern world. This is such a unique opportunity to work with students in another country, and to travel and learn about a culture, through our own research and curation, that is structured around such prominent historical catastrophe, and which continue to shape social and political structures today. This is certainly an experience that we will hold for the rest of our lives and that will shape the way we interact with the world!

Hello!



Who we are
We are 15 students from the Rhode Island School of Design and Brown University taking a course this semester called 「Dialogue Across the Diaspora: Haiti, South Africa, Art, and Narratives of Resistance.」 
The course looks at art and stories created in historically catastrophic circumstances. Though they are very different countries with very different histories, both Haiti and South Africa were shaped by slavery and the ensuing racial discrimination.  


What We Are Doing

story:
Get Veteran African Artists Back to Work

With paints, acrylics, canvas, brushes, palette
knives, etc - shipped to them in Kenya

 

I am Ghanaian Osei G. Kofi. I am passionate about art. Especially contemporary art out of Africa. I became a collector of sorts during my travels. I mentored a few artists in Eastern Africa, some of whom made it into international limelight. I would like to introduce to you some of my former protégés who like me today are, well, gentlemen of a certain age!

                    Wanyu Brush, Sane Wadu & Jak Katarikawe

Kenyans Wanyu Brush and Sane Wadu and Ugandan Jak Katarikawe are self-taught artists. They have achieved international fame with their art: contemporary, homegrown, and in the best traditions of fine art. Their masterpieces hang in of some of the world’s best museums and in private collections.

  • And yet Wanyu, Sane and Jak are unable to work, much. Why? Because vital ingredients of their profession such as oil paints, acrylics, canvas and brushes are difficult to find in many parts of Africa. And when they find some in stock, the stuff cost an arm and a leg; a mighty drain on their earnings.

    Wanyu , Sane and Jak are desperate for supplies to be shipped to them in East Africa – so they can continue to create art – which to them is like breathing.

  • I am here at Indiegogo to crowd source and raise 15,000 US dollars, to cover a year’s supply of canvas, oils, acrylics, thinners, stretcher bars, brushes, palette knives, etc, for Wanyu, Sane and Jak and some of their colleagues.

  • In Their Own Words …

  • Sane Wadu, 55, “I don’t mind when I go hungry. But I go nuts when I can’t find canvas or paint, to release these angels, or wild things constantly screaming inside me, demanding that I set them free!!” Sane says. He was once nicknamed “Insane” by neighbours in his hometown in Central Kenya after he grew a beard and resigned his elementary school teacher’s job, in order to paint fulltime. Years later the neighbours changed their moniker to “Sane” when they saw “important people” drive to the village asking for “Mr Wadu”, to buy his art.

                                    

                                  Sane Wadu-9/11 New York-When The Twin Towers Fell

    •  

     Where are you, Mayor Bloomberg, Sir? Come for your art. Here is the thing. On that fateful September day in New York, Sane Wadu, in far away Kenya, sat transfixed by the horror on his TV screen, as people jumped from windows of the Twin Towers, preferring quicker death to the inferno engulfing them. That night, Sane feverishly set to work on a canvas. The result is one of the most trenchant, pathos suffused of his oeuvres to date: 9/11 New York.  “It belongs to the brave people of New York,” he said, adding, “I’ve been waiting all these years for the mayor to come for it for City Hall - or for someone in America to own it.”

     

    Wanyu Brush in his Nairobi studio ... Dwindling materials.

     

    Wanyu Brush, 62, gets into an even more lamentable state when he’s unable to create. “Please, stay away from me if I haven’t painted for a month for lack of materials – you might bear the brunt of me losing my marbles in your presence” he says. In 2008 more than 1,000 Kenyans were killed in political violence following disputed presidential elections. Since then, Wanyu has painted 20 canvases in his signature horror vacui style, depicting the ghastly bloodletting. He has since used up his stock of canvas and oils, even brushes. “These works are my catharsis. I would have gone totally mad if I couldn’t paint for lack of materials when the killings started,” he says.

    Btw, Wanyu is Swahili meaning “I am your.” Imagine an artist, a painter, whose name is “I am your brush!”

     

Wanyu Brush - I am your brush ...

 

 

Jak Katarikawe and an unfinished work ... for lack of oils

 

Jak Katarikawe, 76, Some call him Africa’s Chagall, for his hovering figures, vibrant colours and unique use of romantic imagery. The dream world is intrinsic to Katarikawe, East Africa’s most renown fine artist, with a personal life as rich and fascinating as the soothing, mirthful images he’s poured onto paper, cardboard and canvas for over 50 years. A joyous naivety and poetic fantasy permeate Katarikawe’s impressionism, where there is no separation between the human and the animal worlds. His long horned cows, elephants, birds and zebras smile, laugh, make love, scheme, cheat, fight, marry, divorce, remarry. “Everything I paint is from my dreams,” he says.

Jak Katarikawe - I am Happy, I wasn't barren after all

 

Jak, Sane and Wanyu are gifted chroniclers of emergent Africa, with its joys, tribulations, hopes and undeniable achievements. We need them to continue to be present, strong in their social engagements through their art. They enrich their communities, Africa and the world at large.

Despite their early success times are hard for these artists. They are the main breadwinners in their extended African families. Cash earned from their art is never theirs alone. It sustains the family unit, numbering from a dozen to about fifty close relatives – for food, clothing, education, health care …

Sane Wadu - A President on the Cross-Shall We Crucify Him?

  

Own a piece of them. When you donate, you may also tell them your dream. They will draw or paint your dream and gift it to you. These artists will definitely loom large in time and enter into posterity.

 

I was a foreign correspondent, who for many years covered the growing pains of
post-independence Africa - in Angola, Burundi, DRC, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Liberia,
Mozambique, Namibia, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, Somalia, South Africa, Southern
Sudan, Zimbabwe ... I also worked for 14 years for UNICEF, helping to create
awareness and raise cash to fund activities of the world’s children’s body in some
of the poorest regions of the world. These days I curate art and write for
magazines and in the social media. Seeing contemporary art out of Africa
finally carving a vibrant niche on the international stage is great oomph!
(Kofi)

 

You Can Help - with $15, $25, $100 or $1000.

Garnering more than the $15,000 target of this campaign will allow Wanyu, Sane and Jak to extend your largesse to other  struggling colleagues too.

 

They will all be infinitely grateful, you helping them along their journey.

 

Asante Sana (thank you).
