story:
Who We Are:

We are Eclectic, an artist co-op, located in the heart of Downtown Urbana. We have been here since March of 2010. We serve as a hub for local artists to connect with one another and share their diverse work with the community. The idea is simple: we want to make art accessible to anyone and everyone by redefining who is allowed to be creative. Everything in the store is made by artists who are everyday people who love keeping their creative passions alive.

During the past few months, there have been many developments to bring new businesses to the downtown area.  We are very excited to welcome our new neighbors and to collaborate in the revitalization of Downtown Urbana. We recognize that one key ingredient in the process of revitalization is creativity, which is something we see throughout the businesses in the downtown area. But another key component of revitalization is community support. We are asking for our community to support us as we are recovering from the hard times we have faced as a result of the construction in Downtown Urbana.  We are looking to raise $16,000 to keep our store open - $8500 of which we hope to raise through Indiegogo.  

The strength of our community of artists is demonstrated by the fact that they have donated their art for our fundraising art sales and have paid for memberships six months in advance to raise $4500. The artists and our downtown neighboring businesses have also generously donated additional items to be auctioned during our Save Eclectic fundraising event at Crane Alley on August 27th.  We hope to raise an additional $3000 through this event.  

The Need:

This leaves $8500 more to be raised through Indiegogo in order for our local artists to continue sharing their creative work with the community. If we fail to reach our goal, we will have to face the reality of closing our doors before being able to reap the benefits of all the hard work being done to revitalize our downtown.

So we are turning to you, our community, for support.

The $8500 will specifically cover our past due artist commissions, which they have patiently deferred to keep Eclectic afloat through the revitalization process.  Combined with the funds we have already raised, this will cover rent and overhead and carry us to the Holiday season.  

The Perks

To say thank you for helping us, our artists have pulled together and created some terrific perks. These perks can be a special something for yourself or be given as a gift to a loved one or friend! We've posted the perks on the sidebar, but check out the photos below to see the kind of local art pieces you will receive for partnering with us!

How you can help!

1) Support our Indiegogo campaign and get a cool perk for yourself or to give as a gift!

2) Follow us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram, and help us spread the word by mentioning us and using the hashtag #SaveEclectic. Even, if you can’t give, will you donate a Tweet or Facebook post to help us spread the word?

3) Come visit us at Eclectic: an artist co-op from 11am - 5pm on Tuesday through Saturday!

Thanks so much for all your help to Save Eclectic and Keep Creativity Alive for local artists in Downtown Urbana!

Sincerely,

Susan Pryde // Owner and Director of Eclectic: an artist co-op

story:
The Mighty Fingers Story

This project is the culmination of many years of travel, witness, and action.  It fuels all parts of me, and brings the best that I can offer to the world while I am alive on this planet.  For over twenty years, I have been a pioneer in the field of collaborative art and founder of FingerSmears (my signature method of collaborative painting).
 I am fiercely dedicated to the use of art for social change, and I understand that the empowerment of girls - particularly in impoverished areas, is the first step in creating lasting change to end the cycle of poverty.   I am also a professional fine art painter, absorbed in the study of classical oil painting.  Making art inspires me.

In my two decades of creating collaborative art FingerSmears™ I have had over 80,000 people stick their fingers in paint to contribute to my community focused FingerSmear™ paintings. Through MIGHTY FINGERS FACING CHANGE, I happily combine my FingerSmear™ work with my fine art by offering my talent and experience to help empower the next generation of change-makers.  We have produced this fun, empowering, collaborative project in six locations around the world so far; Quetzaltenango, Guatemala - Edmonton, Canada, - San Francisco CA, Jackson WY, Port-Au-Prince and Jacmel, Haiti, and Santa Caloma, Spain.  This campaign will help bring Mighty Fingers Facing Change to location number 7 - Uganda in December of 2015. Please join us as we engage, create, and celebrate the power of these mighty fingers to transform their village through art and education. 

We will be bringing Mighty Fingers Facing Change to Amor Village in Uganda to work with The Pearl Community Empowerment Foundation: a non-profit grassroots organization dedicated to empowering rural African communities to take charge of their own development and break the cycle of poverty. This campaign will help us cover production expenses, supplies, documentation, accommodations, and it will also help to outfit the village's first school house.  This six room building has been built from handmade bricks and the labor of the village to help ensure a better future for their children. They are working hard to finish the roof and plaster the walls for our arrival.  We want to help purchase the 150 desks that will serve them for generations.  We will also be bringing school supplies and art supplies. Thank you for supporting this project.  We look forward to sharing the experience with all of you.  http://pce-foundation.org/

Education begins early.

Walls go up in the six room school house.

The Mighty Fingers Self-Portrait Project

In each location we use art to empower.  We have conversations about community, our place in it, our opinions about it, and our visions for it.  We use words and symbols to encourage creative thought.  We listen, and we guide.  The girls come to know themselves more deeply, and discover their own might.  They create a self-portrait based on that experience. They build critical thinking skills by using paint and their fingers to  translate their feelings and dreams into a piece of art that makes a statement about their own beauty and strength.  This self-portrait painting is created on a bag so they can symbolically fill that vessel with poems, letters, school work - whatever inspires them and keeps them on their own path. 

GAP!, Alta Elementary School, & Teton Science School show their Mighty Fingers

Gema shows her work, and her message.  Hear what she has to say in the Guatemala Mighty Fingers Video in the Extra's section. 

The Global FingerSmear™
One canvas, over 1,000 girls.  "Abundance" is the name of our 10' long FingerSmear™ canvas that travels with us to each Mighty Fingers location.  All of the girls add their mark and their name to this collaborative piece of art that ties them all together. 

The Global FingerSmear™ get it's first touches in Guatemala. 

Colors come out in Jackson, Wyoming

"Dream Big! FingerSmears connects our young women to their big dreams, power, hope, and love through this unique, artistic, creative, experience.  Boys and Girls Club of San Francisco is honored to be part of Kelly Sullivan's amazing legacy of community building - one finger painted stroke at a time." Pat Zemora, Boys and Girls Club of San Francisco, Citywide Arts Programs. 

Working with three different organizations in Haiti, "Abundance" comes along.

The Documentation
Videographer Toni Tru travels to each Mighty Fingers location, giving the girls a platform to spread their views and opinions through video and digital media.  She also enlists the participation of the girls by having them operate equipment, and learn about staging and lighting and sound.  They love watching the playbacks on site, but more importantly, all of the girls, past - present, and future, can watch and share the video for a greater understanding of the connection they have to 'sisters' around the world.  Her work creates a powerful tool not only for the girls but the organizations that we work through.  She is also a great traveler who always has the right gadgets to get us where we need to go. 

Toni Tru shows the ins and outs of setting the shoot.  See her work and hear their voices in the Extras section.

The Exchange
In each location the girls make something that we bring to the next location - A postcard, or a small piece of art.  We have a stack of cards made by girls in Santa Caloma Spain that we will bring to the girls in Amor Village.  The girls in Amor Village will make a little something that we will bring to our next location - India. 

Girls in Haiti show off their messages from girls in San Francisco and Canada.

The Result
Empowered, connected, inspired girls.  And we get a kick out of it too.  Thank you for believing in me, and the work we can do.  Thank you for believing that art does create a better world, and supporting it with your 'perks'.  Thank you for helping to uplift these beautiful ladies into a stronger, more powerful, and healthy place.  It's a wonderful multi-generational solution that is at the root of creating lasting change.
story_txt:
The Mighty Fingers Story

This project is the culmination of many years of travel, witness, and 
action.  It fuels all parts of me, and brings the best that I can offer 
to the world while I am alive on this planet.  For over twenty years, I have been a pioneer in the field of collaborative art and founder of FingerSmears (my signature method of collaborative painting).  I am fiercely dedicated to the use of art for social change, and I understand that the empowerment of girls - particularly in impoverished areas, is the first step in creating lasting change to end the cycle of poverty.   I am also a professional fine art painter, absorbed in the study of classical oil painting.  Making art inspires me. 

In my two decades of creating collaborative art FingerSmears™ I have had over 80,000 people stick their fingers in paint to contribute to my community focused FingerSmear™ paintings. Through MIGHTY FINGERS FACING CHANGE, I happily combine my FingerSmear™ work with my fine art by offering my talent and experience to help empower the next generation of change-makers.  We have produced this fun, empowering, collaborative project in six locations around the world so far; Quetzaltenango, Guatemala - Edmonton, Canada, - San Francisco CA, Jackson WY, Port-Au-Prince and Jacmel, Haiti, and Santa Caloma, Spain.  This campaign will help bring Mighty Fingers Facing Change to location number 7 - Uganda in December of 2015. Please join us as we engage, create, and celebrate the power of these mighty fingers to transform their village through art and education.  


We will be bringing Mighty Fingers Facing Change to Amor Village in Uganda to work with The Pearl Community Empowerment Foundation: a non-profit grassroots organization dedicated to empowering rural African
 communities to take charge of their own development and break the cycle
 of poverty. This campaign will help us cover production expenses, supplies, documentation, accommodations, and it will also help to outfit the village's first school house.  This six room building has been built from handmade bricks and the labor of the village to help ensure a better future for their children. They are working hard to finish the roof and plaster the walls for our arrival.  We want to help purchase the 150 desks that will serve them for generations.  We will also be bringing school supplies and art supplies. Thank you for supporting this project.  We look forward to sharing the experience with all of you.  http://pce-foundation.org/

Education begins early.



Walls go up in the six room school house. 
The Mighty Fingers Self-Portrait Project
In each location we use art to empower.  We have conversations about community, our place in it, our opinions about it, and our visions for it.  We use words and symbols to encourage creative thought.  We listen, and we guide.  The girls come to know themselves more deeply, and discover their own might.  They create a self-portrait based on that experience. They build critical thinking skills by using paint and their fingers to  translate their feelings and dreams into a piece of art that makes a statement about their own beauty and strength.  This self-portrait painting is created on a bag so they can symbolically fill that vessel with poems, letters, school work - whatever inspires them and keeps them on their own path.  

GAP!, Alta Elementary School, & Teton Science School show their Mighty Fingers

Gema shows her work, and her message.  Hear what she has to say in the Guatemala Mighty Fingers Video in the Extra's section.  

The Global FingerSmear™One canvas, over 1,000 girls.  "Abundance" is the name of our 10' long FingerSmear™ canvas that travels with us to each Mighty Fingers location.  All of the girls add their mark and their name to this collaborative piece of art that ties them all together.  
The Global FingerSmear™ get it's first touches in Guatemala.  

Colors come out in Jackson, Wyoming

"Dream Big! FingerSmears connects our young women to their big dreams, power, hope, and love through this unique, artistic, creative, experience.  Boys and Girls Club of San Francisco is honored to be part of Kelly Sullivan's amazing legacy of community building - one finger painted stroke at a time." Pat Zemora, Boys and Girls Club of San Francisco, Citywide Arts Programs.  

Working with three different organizations in Haiti, "Abundance" comes along. 
The DocumentationVideographer Toni Tru travels to each Mighty Fingers location, giving the girls a platform to spread their views and opinions through video and digital media.  She also enlists the participation of the girls by having them operate equipment, and learn about staging and lighting and sound.  They love watching the playbacks on site, but more importantly, all of the girls, past - present, and future, can watch and share the video for a greater understanding of the connection they have to 'sisters' around the world.  Her work creates a powerful tool not only for the girls but the organizations that we work through.  She is also a great traveler who always has the right gadgets to get us where we need to go.  
Toni Tru shows the ins and outs of setting the shoot.  See her work and hear their voices in the Extras section. 

The ExchangeIn each location the girls make something that we bring to the next location - A postcard, or a small piece of art.  We have a stack of cards made by girls in Santa Caloma Spain that we will bring to the girls in Amor Village.  The girls in Amor Village will make a little something that we will bring to our next location - India.  
Girls in Haiti show off their messages from girls in San Francisco and Canada. 
The ResultEmpowered, connected, inspired girls.  And we get a kick out of it too.  Thank you for believing in me, and the work we can do.  Thank you for believing that art does create a better world, and supporting it with your 'perks'.  Thank you for helping to uplift these beautiful ladies into a stronger, more powerful, and healthy place.  It's a wonderful multi-generational solution that is at the root of creating lasting change.

story:
We are: Shani Strand. Sarah Rose Lejeune. Jana Herman. Adam Schachner. Tinni Bhattacharyya. Brent Shaeffer. Sophie Hess. (A gaggle of girls + Adam) 

We are participating in a practicum of collaborative media production, culminating in an editioned book project. We are artists from a range of backgrounds: drawing, creative writing, photography, printmaking, painting, video arts, and sculptural paperwork. Given the diversity of our pre-existing skillsets, we are excited to explore various techniques within the theme of collection. Our goal is to develop a body of work that is visually and conceptually cohesive.

We have chosen collections as a conceptual and literal theme for our collaboration.

Collections brings together a variety of things that may or may not be related on a surface level, but are defined as a unit according to the collector. In this sense we are producing a collection of work that represents the diversity and cohesion of our collaboration. As a group we represent a collection of processes and interests.

Collections are not limited; they are an amassing of materials, a preservation and a combination of ideas, they are inherently composed of mixed elements, can be works of writing, but most significantly collections are distinct because they highlight anomalies amongst similarities. Collections recognize particularities in relation to a whole, which is the epicenter of collaboration.

We are interested in our project culminating in a formal edition of 15 books with three chapters: objects without sentiment, proof, and rituals of repetition, as well as several side projects including two curated shows of our work that also accept submissions from students beyond our collaboration.

What We Need & What You Get

Ultimately, we need to raise about $2,000 dollars. This cost is is the amount of material and process expenses:
Printing Materials 
Paper Making Equipment & Paper 
Book Binding Materials 
Distributional Supplies
Exhibition Fees 
+ Other Miscellaneous Materials (latex, plastic, blender) 

If you do chose to donate we have created 4 marks at which different objects of gratitude will be given. 
If you donate $20.00 or more you will receive 3 personally designed and printed postcards, created by one or several of our members. 
If you donate $50.00 or more you will receive 7 personally designed and printed postcards, created by one or several of our members. One for every member of our collective! 
If you donate $100.00 or more you will receive a surprise package that will include a collection of artworks and objects created by members - these could range from prints, posters, book pages, photographs, and poems to small collected objects and mixtapes. 

If we do not reach our ultimate goal the amount of money raised will still be going towards the production of this book. It will just be harder for each of us personally. 

If you donate you will receive a digital pdf of the book. *No matter how small the donation. 

****We will try to continuously update this page with snapshots and glimpses of our project and progress****

Other Ways You Can Help

If it is not personally feasible for you to donate please do us a favor and share our campaign with others in the hopes that it will find it's way to someone who may. Money is hard, we get it (literally, it's why we have this campaign), be a friend, spread the word!

story:
Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Discovering Our HeARTS

Plein air painting tour across America from Utah to Maine, while spreading patriotism and our love of country. As I paint, we will also be documenting the interesting & intimate stories behind each work of art. The climax of our tour will finish with a One Man Art Show at the prestigious Springville Museum Of Art in Central Utah, the paintings of the places we visited and our adventurous stories to tell.

 

I grew up in an artist family...so naturally, visual art is my undying passion. My wife Karen also has family members who are artists., making us like two peas in a pod! The two of us have been offered a great opportunity to live and work in Presque Isle, Maine (  https://www.visitmaine.com/organization/presque-isle-area-chamber-of-commerce?uid=vtm504BC79408E6C1170 ) as an artist in residence for one year. Yes, it is a long way from Utah, but that’s actually great! Why?...because we are going to take our time to drive out to Maine, stopping nearly every day to plein air paint on location from state to state! In case you don’t know what a plein air artist is, the term “en plein air” was coined by the original french impressionists, which simply means to paint out in the open air. They aimed to capture the freshness of the atmosphere and the movement of light. Here's an example of one of my "en plein air" studies;

At some of the places we stop for a day or two, we will set up an OUTDOOR TRAVELING ART SHOW. More examples of my artwork can be found here ( www.russellricksart.com )


Once we get to Maine, I'll be off plein air painting along the timeless Maine coastline, an Amish farmers barn ( http://amishamerica.com/maine-amish/ ), a historic building with unmistakable character,



down by a nearby lake or off somewhere else in the New England area. My wife will collect the interesting stories and facts behind each painting. We plan to drive out to Maine in early September 2014, stopping along the way here and there, to paint, collect and discover life in rural America-- the people, their passions and their spirit!

We're calling this project Painting the HeART of America Tour! After a year, we will return to our home in the west sometime in August of 2015 to Central Utah, following a different route home and again stopping along the way to paint and gather more of the stories people have to tell. We also plan to blog about our exciting adventures along the way so you can be updated on how our project is progressing ( http://paintingtheheartofamerica.wordpress.com/  ).

The efforts of all our hard work will culminate in a One Man Show at the prestigious Springville, Utah Museum of Art in September 9th through October 5th, 2015. http://www.smofa.org The Springville Museum show is firm and our goal is to have 30 of my finest paintings and some of our most charming plein air sketches framed and hung in the famous SMA museum.

Contribute, then  get on our mailing list then join us at the Artist Reception opening night of the show. With you on our list we will be sure to let you know the night of the show via special V.I.P. invitation. We can't wait to get started and hope you'll join us on our adventure!

Russell & Karen Ricks

P.S. Here's how you can join us on our tour and help make it all possible!

What We Need & The Perks You'll Get In Return!

WHAT YOU GET! 

In return for your generous pledge, we want to give you a reward as a way of saying thank you for making our dream a reality!

We have some exciting PERKS for your generous gifts in return. The PERKS are outlined in detail in the column to your right. For example; A frameable 5x7 inch postcard of one of my original paintings, T-Shirts with our tour logo and sponsors on it, 5x7 inch signed and numbered gilclee prints on quality paper, original hand painted 6x8, 8x10 inch, and 9x12 inch plein air quick studies and finished larger paintings of my original work. We are excited and we can't wait to return the favor to you as we embark on this ambitious adventure!

Frameable Postcards, 8x10 Limited Edition Gilclee Prints, T-Shirts with our tour logo, Plein Air Quick Studies and Framed Paintings!

Prints!

Plein Air Quick Studies!

Framed Oil Paintings!

Frameable Post Cards & T-Shirts!


WHAT WE NEED

In order to really fulfill this adventure and travel to those unique picturesque "best kept secret" places to paint on location, meet the people and tell their stories, we will need the finances to do so. We are looking for people to be a part of our adventure by pledging a $ dollar amount and in return you get some really cool rewards! We estimate overall it will cost us $25,900 and if we do raise even more than our estimate, THIS IS GOOD!, because we will be able to go more places, paint more paintings and meet more genuine American regular folk! Below is a list of items we are hoping to secure though crowd funding for our tour...

RELIABLE USED VEHICLE-- A reliable used car with low mileage, good MPH and more space. We are looking for a good used Mini Van or SUV. Our 2001 Honda Civic has been a great car, but now the transmission is going out. If anyone has a vehicle as we described above that runs great and would like to trade for an original painting, we would love to deal!

GASOLINE-- We will do our best to find the best price for unleaded gas, wherever we need to fill up our tank. If we have extra by the time we get to Presque Isle, Maine, we will use this budget to travel and plein air paint somewhere in the New England Area. The money will be used wisely.

LODGING-- We won't always be able to camp outside and plan to stay in a motel or two on the road. Wherever possible, we hope to prearrange with friends, family or the hospitality of people who live along the route we will travel to cut this cost down as much as possible.

FOOD -- An artist needs to eat...REALLY! I refuse to be a starving artist (and I don't want my wife Sammee to starve either)! As often as we can, we will buy groceries at your local ma & pop country market to trim the cost of eating out too much. We are looking at a food budget at about $700. If you would like to have us over for dinner when we are in your town, we would love to meet you and this would help us out a lot!

ADVERTISING-- This budget is for covering the cost of T-Shirts, business cards, frameable 5 x 7 postcards with examples of my original artwork, signage for our tour vehicle (VINYL VEHICLE WRAP) and to advertise our major *SPONSORS

ART SUPPLIES--  For canvases or panels to paint on, artist paint supplies, a few ready-made frames, paint brushes, sketch pads, etc.

EXHIBIT DISPLAY SYSTEM-- We would like to purchase a nice portable display system and a couple of collapsible gazebos for out traveling outdoor art show. 

The Impact

The HEART of the American is not found in any one particular place, but is found within her people-- A people who first came to this land to escape tyranny and dwell in a land where they could live in freedom. Love of Country also rests deep in the heart of our brothers and sisters from all over the world. Art has a universal language and is unifying in nature. As a young boy, growing up surrounded by art everyday, I made lasting bonds of friendship with people from all over America through my father's nationally renown art workshops (Painting Vacations), It was art which brought us all together. As we travel to our final destination, stopping to paint along the way and meeting new people, we hope to remind all Americans that we are all one people and who we are, still lives on deep in our hearts! More than any other time in our rich history, I believe we need to unite together to protect and save this heritage. We must never forget who we truly are and where we all came from!    

Risks & Challenges

    How am I qualified to take on such an ambitious project? Having grown up in an artist family, I've worked as a professional artist most of my life. Ambitious projects are not new to me and I've always been an "outside the box" kind of thinker. I've painted literally very gargantuan-sized indoor murals for some large corporations such as a Cabela's store in Connecticut, Alcoa, Inc branch in Utah, and Utah based Novatek International, to name a few. ( www.themeroommurals.blogspot.com ) When taking on such a project, even by having to burn candles at both ends, I have never failed to fulfill the client's demand and have always finished on time. This painting across America tour is in a way, a gargantuan-sized project and your contribution WILL make it a success! " Like my friend Billy Boots put it, "Positive attitude changes everything!"

    In the case of an unfortunate accident where I kick the bucket for example, we have secured sufficient life insurance for the two of us which could be cashed out to reimburse your pledge if necessary.

    If we don't reach or surpass our pledge amount, our plan is flexible enough that we can cut back on the number of places we will go to fulfill our goals. If we exceed our goal, we will be able to visit and paint in more places on our way out to Maine, perhaps even in your own little rural town!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    EVERYONE CAN HELP AND HERE"S HOW!...If you are unable to contribute, you can still help us out by spreading the word among all your friends on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn or Pintrest! You can even help a lot by giving us tips where we can go to find the subject matter I am looking for to paint... go to www.russellricksart.com and check out my "Works" page to get an idea what I paint. If you would be willing to host us for 1-2 nights, helping us out with food or a place to sleep, we would be grateful. Follow us on Facebook at;https://www.facebook.com/ricks.russell or 

    https://www.facebook.com/ricks.russell. 

    Our blog address is; www.paintingtheheartofamerica.wordpress.com


    When Painting The HeART Of America officially starts our road trip, we will be going to the following states and towns within these states;

    1) Utah-- Green River to;
    2) Colorado-- Grand Junction-- Parker-- Vail to;
    3) Nebraska-- No. Platte, then east on I-80 to;
    4) Iowa-- Council Bluffs-- Walnut, then east on 34, then a day in Dyersville (Field Of Dreams movie site) and the Amish Hazelton-- Cedar Rapids to;
    5) Illinois-- Nauvoo-- Carthage-- Arthur/Danville area to;
    6) Indiana-- Rochester to;
    7) Michigan-- Kinderhook-- Lansing to;
    8) Ohio-- Kirtland to;
    9) New York-- Niagra Falls / Palmyra areas-- Hudson Valley/Catskill Mnts to;
    10) Pennsylvania-- Philadelphia-- Lancaster/Middleton areas to;
    11) Connecticut-- Hartford, Bloomfield and surrounding areas to;
    12) Massachusetts-- Boston-- Springfield to;
    13) Vermont-- Dorset/Bennington to;

    14) New Hamshire-- Tilton/Lake Winnepesaukee to;

    15) MAINE-- Bangor-- Bar Harbor-- and last but not least...

    Presque Isle!

    If you have good-to-know information for these areas or live in or near any of these areas and would be willing to put us up for the night, please let us know!

    Thanks!

    Russell & Karen Ricks

    ricks.russell@gmail.com

If anyone has a vehicle as we described above that runs great and would like to trade for an original painting, we would love to deal!GASOLINE-- We will do our best to find the best price for unleaded gas, wherever we need to fill up our tank. If we have extra by the time we get to Presque Isle, Maine, we will use this budget to travel and plein air paint somewhere in the New England Area. The money will be used wisely.LODGING-- We won't always be able to camp outside and plan to stay in a motel or two on the road. Wherever possible, we hope to prearrange with friends, family or the hospitality of people who live along the route we will travel to cut this cost down as much as possible.FOOD -- An artist needs to eat...REALLY! I refuse to be a starving artist (and I don't want my wife Sammee to starve either)! As often as we can, we will buy groceries at your local ma & pop country market to trim the cost of eating out too much. We are looking at a food budget at about $700. If you would like to have us over for dinner when we are in your town, we would love to meet you and this would help us out a lot!ADVERTISING-- This budget is for covering the cost of T-Shirts, business cards, frameable 5 x 7 postcards with examples of my original artwork, signage for our tour vehicle (VINYL VEHICLE WRAP) and to advertise our major *SPONSORSART SUPPLIES--  For canvases or panels to paint on, artist paint supplies, a few ready-made frames, paint brushes, sketch pads, etc.EXHIBIT DISPLAY SYSTEM-- We would like to purchase a nice portable display system and a couple of collapsible gazebos for out traveling outdoor art show.    The ImpactThe HEART of the American is not found in any one particular place, but is found within her people-- A people who first came to this land to escape tyranny and dwell in a land where they could live in freedom. Love of Country also rests deep in the heart of our brothers and sisters from all over the world. Art has a universal language and is unifying in nature. As a young boy, growing up surrounded by art everyday, I made lasting bonds of friendship with people from all over America through my father's nationally renown art workshops (Painting Vacations), It was art which brought us all together. As we travel to our final destination, stopping to paint along the way and meeting new people, we hope to remind all Americans that we are all one people and who we are, still lives on deep in our hearts! More than any other time in our rich history, I believe we need to unite together to protect and save this heritage. We must never forget who we truly are and where we all came from!       Risks & ChallengesHow am I qualified to take on such an ambitious project? Having grown up in an artist family, I've worked as a professional artist most of my life. Ambitious projects are not new to me and I've always been an "outside the box" kind of thinker. I've painted literally very gargantuan-sized indoor murals for some large corporations such as a Cabela's store in Connecticut, Alcoa, Inc branch in Utah, and Utah based Novatek International, to name a few. ( www.themeroommurals.blogspot.com ) When taking on such a project, even by having to burn candles at both ends, I have never failed to fulfill the client's demand and have always finished on time. This painting across America tour is in a way, a gargantuan-sized project and your contribution WILL make it a success! " Like my friend Billy Boots put it, "Positive attitude changes everything!"In the case of an unfortunate accident where I kick the bucket for example, we have secured sufficient life insurance for the two of us which could be cashed out to reimburse your pledge if necessary.If we don't reach or surpass our pledge amount, our plan is flexible enough that we can cut back on the number of places we will go to fulfill our goals. If we exceed our goal, we will be able to visit and paint in more places on our way out to Maine, perhaps even in your own little rural town!   Other Ways You Can HelpEVERYONE CAN HELP AND HERE"S HOW!...If you are unable to contribute, you can still help us out by spreading the word among all your friends on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn or Pintrest! You can even help a lot by giving us tips where we can go to find the subject matter I am looking for to paint... go to www.russellricksart.com and check out my "Works" page to get an idea what I paint. If you would be willing to host us for 1-2 nights, helping us out with food or a place to sleep, we would be grateful. Follow us on Facebook at;https://www.facebook.com/ricks.russell or https://www.facebook.com/ricks.russell. Our blog address is; www.paintingtheheartofamerica.wordpress.comWhen Painting The HeART Of America officially starts our road trip, we will be going to the following states and towns within these states;1) Utah-- Green River to;2) Colorado-- Grand Junction-- Parker-- Vail to;3) Nebraska-- No. Platte, then east on I-80 to;4) Iowa-- Council Bluffs-- Walnut, then east on 34, then a day in Dyersville (Field Of Dreams movie site) and the Amish Hazelton-- Cedar Rapids to;5) Illinois-- Nauvoo-- Carthage-- Arthur/Danville area to;6) Indiana-- Rochester to;7) Michigan-- Kinderhook-- Lansing to;8) Ohio-- Kirtland to;9) New York-- Niagra Falls / Palmyra areas-- Hudson Valley/Catskill Mnts to;10) Pennsylvania-- Philadelphia-- Lancaster/Middleton areas to;11) Connecticut-- Hartford, Bloomfield and surrounding areas to;12) Massachusetts-- Boston-- Springfield to;13) Vermont-- Dorset/Bennington to;14) New Hamshire-- Tilton/Lake Winnepesaukee to;15) MAINE-- Bangor-- Bar Harbor-- and last but not least...Presque Isle!If you have good-to-know information for these areas or live in or near any of these areas and would be willing to put us up for the night, please let us know!Thanks!Russell & Karen Ricksricks.russell@gmail.com

story:
- View the Gallery Tab for updated progress pictures of the project -

This past May I was elated to learn of my acceptance in Art Prize 2014 in Grand Rapids, Michigan. If you are unfamiliar with Art Prize it is the largest, independently organized, art competition in North America. It receives international attention, encompases the entire city, and this year the grand prize amounts to $200,000 and the opportunity to be exhibited in the Grand Rapids Art Museum. Art Prize is known for its radically open model that allows a large variety of artists to participate and its award system that awards artists based on the votes of the public. To learn more about Art Prize please visit their website at www.artprize.org. This is a very large opportunity for me and it is unique that it should be offered to me this early in my career.


At Art Prize each artist is allowed to have one entry. This can either be a group of paintings that are treated as one, or a singular piece. The venue I have I am displaying at has requested that I create one large painting for the competition. The painting will be six feet tall and twelve feet wide, consisting of three panels, and displayed in their main lobby. This is very exciting for me because my interests have been leading me towards creating large scale work and this competition is giving me the opportunity to do so with the guarantee that it will be shown. This opportunity gives me access to my largest audience yet as last year Art Prize had 400,000 visitors.


However, with this opportunity I have also been asked to stretch beyond my financial capabilities. I do not want this to hinder me from competing in Art Prize and so have applied for grants through Art Prize itself, the Luminarts Foundation, Harpo Foundation, and Working Artist Org; and now I am reaching out to you. After researching the costs of materials, I estimate that the cost of creating, transporting this painting, and fulfilling the perks will be $1550. I am hoping that through my own investment, the winning of grants, support of others, and yourself I will be able to raise the funds to complete this project. Every small bit helps; $25 allows me to buy a tube of paint, $50 buys archival quality primer, $100 covers the materials for one of the three panels. 


Regardless of your decision, I do hope that you would consider joining us for part of Art Prize and viewing the work of all the artists. It runs from September 24th until October 12th, with the first round of voting to select finalist ending on October 4th.


Thank you for your continual support that has helped propel me this far already.


Warm Regards,

Ric Sindt

If you would like to learn more about me please visit my Facebook page at www.facebook.com/ricsindt

story:
Hey!

If you don’t know about this project you can read more here: https://charlavail.wordpress.com/2015/01/25/the-next-project-camper-blog-no-1/

If you do donate $5 or more please select the postcard perk so it will collect your address :)

Soooo.. ehhhhh… uhhh, these things are so hard to start!  I was hoping I wouldn’t have to do this but I’m asking for help with the camper. This entrepreneurial path is still new to me and I’m still learning and this year I encountered a pretty big learning curve with my taxes.  I was told not to talk about my taxes because it’s taboo? But I feel weird not being completely honest with you guys.  It’s not my first year paying income tax but I made more money this year than previous years and I had fewer expenses. I had calculated what I thought my taxes were going to be but I didn’t know about “self employment tax” and well, nearly my entire camper budget was wiped out. I have just about enough money to finish getting the camper ready but I’m hoping to be able to raise some money to get me started on the road. Once I’m on the road I’m hoping the little shop in the camper will make enough money to cover my expenses and it will be self-sufficient.  I believe crowd funding is a phenomenal thing and unfortunately there have been people over the last few years that have abused it and also people who don’t understand it and are ugly towards people that use it this makes it exceptionally difficult to ask for help. I watched Amanda Palmer’s TED Talk a while ago and even though I wasn’t planning to raise money at the time it still really spoke to me. And now that I am asking for help I’m reminding myself of her message and its importance.  This project is about getting connected.  I want to constantly be improving the camper while I’m on the road by stocking up on more art supplies and anything else that will make for better meet ups.  I think I need around $1,500-2,000 to be able to be on the road by the end of the month and to cover expenses for the first 5-7 weeks. This money will go towards putting the finishing touches on the camper, gas, campsites, groceries, etc. Any additional money raised will go towards bettering the camper.  It’s hard to convey what I hope this project will be but based on the feedback I’ve received so far I’m pretty confident most of you share and understand the vision.  If you do donate, thank you a hundred times. I’m so extremely grateful to be able to do what I do and it would be nothing without you guys. 

I’M SO EXCITED! See y’all on the road!

And thank you to Blake (https://soundcloud.com/blakeharnage) for the music! It made it 100x cuter.

Also, there is no pastry/confectionery element to this camper. I keep seeing comments about bakery stuff and that's a different dream. It's a dream I still love but I'm not sure if I'll ever pursue it, but maybe it will be what comes after this!

story:
My name is Shannon, but I am also known as Shantastic Shine.  

I am an artist and I work on a lot of paintings.  I have a dream that I like to call "Paint the Sates".  Paint the States is my dream to get at least one of my paintings in every state by the end of January 2015!  I need YOUR help to fulfill my dream!

The inspiration of this dream came when I was cleaning out my closet and I noticed I had so many paintings, but no where to put them.  I would love to see my art hung up in homes across the country and eventually the world.  I have been gathering names and addresses of those in various states to send out my first shipment in the next 30 days.

Help Me Help You!  I'm a creator it's what I do. 

I spend hours upon hours upon hours of my life creating colorful and unique pieces of art to help the world shine.  Oh yea!  Did I mention that most of them are UV Glow paintings that glow in the dark??  You can even draw on them with UV laser pens!  SHINE TIME!  ALL DAY!

I'm looking to raise a minimum of $500 to go towards shipping fee's for the paintings.  Since most paintings cost more than $10 to ship, it won't cover it all.  I would like to go by donation for these pieces so those who cannot afford one may still have the opportunity to get one.  

Painting the states Round 1 is just the start of a beautiful thing. I would love to grow this project above and beyond and hopefully get a painting in every country at some point! Also, I am looking to do a mural in every state as well so any information or donation on any of my painting endeavors is going to many good uses. Please feel free to send me address' to shantasticshine@gmail.com for the project.

story:
My name is Anna. I have graduated from Stockholm School of Economics in Riga as a Bachelor of Economics and Business Administration in 2001 and have worked in advertising industry for several years. After that I have been engaged in several independent projects and have successfully established my own business at the age of 23. Now I primarily work as a freelance translator of commercial texts.

My previous background definitely has an impact on this project.

The idea of the project is to publish a book of flyers that were designed for the electronic music events that took place in Latvia.

The flyers were playing inalienable part of every electronic music event and now are a great example of graphic design of the 90-ies - 00-ies and a reference to electronic music culture of that period. Flyers almost do not exist now and were mainly substituted by electronic "flyers". The collections of people who have given their flyers for scanning amount to about 500 pieces.

I decided to split the whole fundraising campaign into two parts:

1. technical issues and production

2. introductory article and printing.

This part of campaign is dedicated to the first two steps of the whole publishing process: scanning and digital preparation of materials for design and designing the book.

In order to calculate precisely costs of printing we need to scan all the materials and make a design of a book first. So, the work of graphic designer and technical person has to be paid.

For this we need 1 000 Euro.

For each contribution of 40 Euro (delivery worldwide, postal expenses included)  or 18 Euro (book is to be picked up in Riga) you will get a great book of flyers approximately by the end of 2013.

Sincerely, and hope for your support,
Anna.

story:
My name is Lindsey Doe. I'm a doctor of human sexuality and a Japanese American. The Polytana Sushi Social / SushiX is essentially the lovechild of my Japanese heritage and passion for sexuality. 

This year will be the event's third run. The first year it was held in my office building and included and aerial view of the models, about 80 attendees, and two models lying feet-to-feet under the sky-light stars. 

The second year we went bigger to give attendees more space, feature more models, and express the imagination of Chris Nagata. Nagata is a Japanese sushi chef and a mastermind with the social. While it seems necessary to reign in his majestic ideas, the outcome of letting his creativity unfold is breath-taking. It really was. The second year he built a stage for the models, with a choreographed unveiling. He hired local hair-dressers and make-up artists to elaborate the beauty of the models and while we planned for four models, Nagata went and surprised me with six. Three sets,e ash completely tasteful, unique, and exquisite. That year there were close to 200 people in attendance. With the catering staff we were beyond capacity and a little too close for quarters. 

So this year when Nagata and I sat down to plan the Sushi Social's third year the most important factor for us was to create a social space where guests could comfortably mingle and enjoy the artistic component of the cuisine without a rush to eat before it was gone. We decided to host the event at his restaurant for ambiance and convenience, and halved the amount of tickets available. Instead of a 200+, the evening would be reserved for the first 100 people. 

This seemed very practical and romantic but it felt like we would be leaving out another 100 or so guests. If the event had shown a trend of doubling in size, was it possible 400 people would want the Sushi Social experience? Yes, of course! So with that, Nagata and I reinforced our decision to have lower attendance by offering a second night of the event the following evening. 

This of course meant taking away two full days of restaurant business for our semi-private social party so it was important to set a price which could compensate for the revenue loss. We did so. We casted the models. We planned the sets. We even trained the staff in non-monogamy. 

Indiegogo is our humble effort to bring Nagata's imagination to life and incredibly valuable sexual and relationship education to Missoula, Montana. 

Our hope with this Indiegogo project is to situate the event so it doesn't rely on ticket sales. People who want to come, but can't afford the cost, can apply for scholarships, and the event will be possible regardless of attendance quotas.

The purpose of the event itself is to celebrate relationship diversity and bring more awareness and more understanding to our community about it. While Missoula, Montana is home to a liberal arts university and much of the state's forward-thinkers, it is also a part of a very conservative environment with rigid ideas about monogamy and sexuality. 
The sushi socials are not just celebrations they are educational opportunities and cultural engagement. They teach participants about Japanese tradition and cuisine. They share the stories of poly relationships and involve people in safe conversation about the many consensual ways humans express sexuality. 
People who are unable to attend the event can still participate and support the celebration. People who are financially positioned for the cost of tickets can subsidize the cost for others. 
Compersion. 
If we don't meet campaign goals, no worries. People still get their perks, the event still runs beautifully, and the funds raised are sent to us by Indiegogo. 

Win-win-win.
Note: An additional awesome benefit of this Indiegogo campaign is that it allows me to practice navigating this platform of crowd-sourcing for a Sexplanations Live tour!!!

story:
The story of Sam Brown's amazing visionary art cries out to be told. Sam is humble, peaceful and unbelievably talented. Living in the high desert of Abiquiu, New Mexico near Santa Fe, Sam creates his beautiful art in a stunning variety of mediums.

I am Chris Schlumpf, an award winning documentary film maker and I am asking for help to tell Sam's compelling story. I will go into the desert to document the real man behind the art. Come along with me and experience the breathtaking art that is Sam Brown.

Please give to help make this important film or spread the word to those who can.

that is Sam Brown.Please give to help make this important film or spread the word to those who can.

story:
I must thank Simina Badica, a fellow Romanian and scholar, whose essay 'Historicizing the Absence: The Missing Photographic Documents of Romanian Late Communism' helped me realize the fundamental importance for this project. After reading her brilliant foray, and maybe the only foray, into the realm of visual arts, I realized there is minimal dialogue to be had over the topic of photography. That begs for a change. My cameras are ready. 

           As a former Eastern European Communist country, Romania has known vast suffering and constant subjugation, where deep feelings of exile and loss found little to no relief in the arts, that supreme force that takes the dust off our everyday existence, as Picasso would say. The arts were dead during the Communist regime, and remained under severe scrutiny ever since. My initial intention was to mine and build upon a collective memory much like Stephen Shore's work in the 1970s here in the USA, a collective memory reflected in all surrounding landscapes. Alas, our collective memory is built upon anything but photography.

          An agile Romanian sportswoman with a humanistic bent, trained first in Architecture then Italian Literature and Philosophy at UCBerkeley, with no purpose in sight besides taking a hearty bite out of life. Having dabbled in commercial photography shortly after graduating college, living felt incomplete still. In 2012, after a short stint in Florence as a photography student, the big break happened regarding my life's journey: all ties came to a knot at the mystical age of 29. Since then it didn't take long to want to aspire towards mastery in a field that is ever challenging, universally engaging, politically and socially charged ad infinitum - fine art photography it was. All of that for this - if curiosity about understanding one's personal myth is the secret to enjoying this earthly existence, well then, I am now the happiest human alive. Because Romania is my home, and home is mythical, Romania has become my personal myth. I regard photographing my country as honoring the land that gave birth to me, honoring its past and hopefully redirecting its future towards a more engaged, emphatic future.

          With your help, with my community’s help, a major shift in an entire country’s consciousness will be possible, a shift regarding the arts, history, and the validity of photography as historical artifact. Once finished and delivered in book form, this very project will serve as conceptual platform for an equally important project: visibility for the LGBT community in Romania. Think of yourself as being part of something larger than life that will kick-start change for thousands of people for ever. I am committed body and soul to achieving this goal, and I need your help, today. Anything helps. And if you can spread the word, even better <3

         

          Here is the breakdown of how your donations will be spent (well spent if I may say so):

*For donations of $200 to $500, I will dedicate an entire day to running though the magnificent details of both my current and the upcoming project, culminating in handing you an autographed monograph.

*For the adventurous donor ($500 or more), I will print any photograph of your choice and hand it to you over a splendid dinner at Café Select. 

The funds will be spent on about 100 rolls of film, developing and of course, the trip.

What do you say? Give a helping hand and let’s do this already! Thank you kindly again, to each and all, even if all you had was a pair of eyes browsing these words. It means a world to me for you to have made it thus far.
story_txt:
I must thank Simina Badica, a fellow Romanian and scholar, whose essay
'Historicizing the Absence: The Missing Photographic Documents of Romanian Late
Communism' helped me realize the fundamental importance for this project. After reading her brilliant foray, and maybe the only foray, into the realm of visual arts, I realized there is minimal dialogue to be had
over the topic of photography. That begs for a change. My cameras are ready.            As
a former Eastern European Communist country, Romania has known vast suffering
and constant subjugation, where deep feelings of exile and loss found little to
no relief in the arts, that supreme force that takes the dust off our everyday
existence, as Picasso would say. The arts were dead during the Communist
regime, and remained under severe scrutiny ever since. My initial intention was
to mine and build upon a collective memory much like Stephen Shore's work in
the 1970s here in the USA, a collective memory reflected in all surrounding
landscapes. Alas, our collective memory is built upon anything but photography.

story:
(English version below)

CHI SIAMO - ASSOCIAZIONE CULTURALE TOOLKIT

L'Associazione Toolkit nasce nel 2011 da un gruppo di giovani artisti e curatori riunitisi attorno a Martin Romeo, artista e allora studente dell'Università IUAV di Venezia. L'obiettivo che si propone il gruppo è quello di contribuire allo sviluppo e alla vitalità culturale della città di Venezia e del suo territorio, tramite l'ideazione la progettazione e la gestione di eventi e manifestazioni artistiche.

Nel corso degli anni l'Associazione ha promosso numerosi giovani artisti under 35 provenienti da tutto il mondo, mettendoli in contatto con studenti, cittadini e istituzioni culturali della città lagunare. Il punto focale su cui si fonda l'azione dell'associazione è l'arte digitale, alla base anche del suo principale progetto, il Toolkit Festival, mirato a sviluppare la creatività, la conoscenza delle arti digitali e forme di co-creazione culturale partecipative.

Al Festival, l'Associazione ha affiancato nel tempo altre attività volte a descrivere l’ampio raggio di possibilità espressive contenute nell’arte interattiva, una tipologia di approccio al contemporaneo capace di trascendere i generi e aprirsi a contributi sonori, visivi, plastici e perfomativi in costante mutamento, grazie soprattutto all’uso della tecnologia. 

Grazie a workshop, talk e tavole rotonde, eventi culturali, Toolkit è riuscito a creare un tessuto di relazioni all'interno del territorio veneziano e tra esso e numerose realtà internazionali.

Dal 2013, l'Associazione Culturale Toolkit è iscritta al Registro Comunale delle Associazioni di Venezia, l'Associazione è apartitica, aconfessionale e non ha fini di lucro.

                                                 Mauro Ferrario - AudioPaintingVisual (Toolkit 2012)

TOOLKIT FESTIVAL

Toolkit Festival vuole porsi come punto di incontro e di riferimento per giovani artisti emergenti (italiani e non) che si muovono nel campo delle arti neomediali. La kermesse vuole inoltre favorire l'avvicinamento a questo ramo dell'arte contemporanea da parte di un pubblico ampio, coinvolgendo nelle sue attività istituzioni, università e giovani italiani ed esteri.

Il Festival, sviluppato nell'arco di tre giorni, propone un ampio ventaglio di esperienze, che spaziano da seminari a mostre interattive, da concerti di musica sperimentale a spettacoli di danza, videoinstallazioni e performance artistiche in diversi luoghi della città, con l'intento di rendere questo percorso artistico e formativo fruibile da un pubblico il più possibile eterogeneo.

Un'altra componente fondamentale è quella didattica, sviluppata attraverso workshop aperti a tutti e realizzati in contemporanea al festival o nei mesi che lo precedono, al fine di far conoscere e sperimentare in prima persona alcuni dei principali software di interattività basati sull’utilizzo di supporti audio e video, e rendere così sempre più accessibile la new media art al visitatore.

Al centro della proposta viene quindi a trovarsi lo spettatore stesso, invitato a svolgere un ruolo attivo attraverso l’interazione fisica sia con l’opera sia con gli spazi che la espongono. All'interno delle mostre e durante le performance proposte dagli artisti, il pubblico è stato infatti coinvolto in prima persona e chiamato a partecipare attivamente alla realizzazione della stessa opera d’arte

                                                                          Andrea Santini - Oscilla (Toolkit 2012)

TOOLKIT FESTIVAL 4° Edizione - COMPOSITIONAL PHASES 

27-28-29 novembre 2014
Seeking new experimental artistic forms connected to interactive technology 

Tre giorni a Venezia con artisti internazionali: Installazioni, Audio/Visual Performance e Live Media 
Artisti selezionati tramite bando internazionale
Spazi espositivi: Officina delle Zattere, Chiesa Santa Maria della Visitazione e Chiostro degli Artigianelli
Eventi collaterali: Live Perfomance saranno ospitati nella chiesa sconsacrata di Santa Maria della Visitazione
Switch Festival: Sezione dedicata allo scambio di lavori in streaming o in documentazione video dei rispettivi festival coinvolti alla manifestazione

CONCEPT

L'utilizzo della tecnologia in campo artistico ha permesso tanto la sperimentazione di nuove forme espressive quanto il ripensamento di quelle tradizionali, lasciando però ad esse sempre il margine necessario ad esprimersi e perché potessero essere valorizzate. Le caratteristiche principali dell'arte tecnologica sono quelle di non intaccare il supporto a cui si relaziona e, per la sua natura digitale, di rispondere a delle azioni restituendo delle immagini. Queste stesse immagini, recepite dallo spettatore, entrano a far parte del suo bagaglio esperienziale e alimentano la co-creazione artistica nel momento performativo. La nuova forma d'arte deriva dalla rielaborazione, per mezzo del binomio arte-tecnologia, di diverse forme artistiche, con l’obiettivo di creare un dialogo nell'arte contemporanea finalizzato alla ricerca di una nuova maturità dell'arte digitale, che vada oltre approcci prevalentemente ludici o scenografici/spettacolari.

La quarta edizione del Toolkit Festival, intitolata Compositional Phases, si focalizzerà quindi sul riadattamento digitale dell'opera, e sulla modularità delle fasi che costituiscono tale progetto artistico. 

Ciò che si chiede agli artisti è che siano messi in luce i diversi stadi dell’elaborazione del progetto all'interno dell'ambiente espositivo: l'opera compiuta e presentata al Festival deve quindi essere in grado di esprimere, e comunicare al visitatore, almeno uno degli aspetti che costituiscono la progettazione e l'esecuzione delle diverse fasi: dal riadattamento dell'opera per mezzo della tecnologia fino alla sua versione rappresentativa-digitale all'interno degli spazi espositivi che ospiteranno il Festival.

Le attività dell'Associazione sono da sempre autofinanziate, gratuite e aperte a tutti, anche un tuo piccolo contributo potrà aiutarci a sostenere le spese organizzative e gestionali del Festival, e a promuovere giovani artisti da tutto il mondo, su un palcoscenico d'eccezione come quello veneziano. Le donazioni saranno totalmente reinvestite nella produzione del Festival, per sostenere le spese di materiali, promozione e alloggio degli artisti partecipanti.

GRAZIE 
Toolkit Staff

Per maggiori informazioni visita il nostro sito
www.toolkitfestival.com 

Anni Garza Lau - Enviromental Disturbancies (Toolkit 2013)


WHO WE ARE - TOOLKIT CULTURAL ASSOCIATION

The Toolkit Association was founded in 2011 by a group of young artists and curators gathered around the artist and then IUAV University student Martin Romeo. The group’s objective is to contribute to the cultural liveliness of Venice and its mainland.

The Association promoted numerous young artists – mostly under 35 - from all over the world in its years of activity. During this experience the young artist were connected to students, citizens and Venice’s cultural institutions. Toolkit Festival is the Association’s main digital art project, being media art the center of the group’s activity. The Festival’s aim is to develop creativity, knowledge of the digital arts and of co-creational participative cultural forms.

While working on the Toolkit Festival project, the Association involved itself in activities concerning the vast sphere of interactive art’s spectrum of possibilities and expressions: a resourceful approach that transcends the genres and opens up to acoustic, visual and plastic contributions, creating constantly changing performances aided by the use of technology.

Thanks to workshops, talks , round-tables and cultural events Toolkit put together many different people and weaved relationships that spread throughout the Venetian territory, between the Festival itself and many other local international realities.

Since 2013 the Toolkit Cultural Association has been part of the Municipalities’ Association Register. The association is non-politic, non-denominational and non profit.  

                                       Lorenz Potthast - The Decelerator Helmet (Toolkit 2013)

TOOLKIT FESTIVAL

Toolkit Festival wants to be a meeting point, a reference for the young emerging Italian and international artists that operate in the new media field. The festival wants to encourage a vast public to approach to this branch of contemporary art by involving the city’s institutions, the University and the Italian and international youth.

The three day festival presents a vast spectrum of experiences in different locations of Venice, from seminars to interactive shows, experimental music concerts, dance shows, video installations and artistic performances, the artistic and formative itinerary wants to address the most heterogeneous public possible.

Another fundamental component of our work is the educational aspect, which has been developed through open workshops held during the Festival or in the previous months. The aim is to spread knowledge and render new media art accessible by allowing the public to experiment in first person some of the main interactive software programs based on audiovisual aids.

The spectator himself is the center of our artistic proposal, he plays an active role physically interacting with the art work and the space in which it is exposed. During shows and performances the public has been involved in first person and called to participate actively to the production of the art work itself.

    Caroline Liebl & Nikolas Schmid-Pfaehler, Vincent und Emily (Toolkit 2013)

TOOLKIT FESTIVAL 4° Edition - COMPOSITIONAL PHASES

November 27-28-29 2014
Seeking new experimental artistic forms connected to interactive technology

Three days in Venice with International artists:Installations, Audio/Visual Performance and Live Media
The artist have been selected by an international call
Exposition spaces: Officina delle Zattere, Chiesa Santa Maria della Visitazione and Chiostro degli Artigianelli
Collateral events: live performances will be hosted in the unconsecrated church of Santa Maria della Visitazione
Switch Festival: this section is dedicated to the exchange of streamed works or to the video documentation of each festival involved in the event

CONCEPT

The use of technology in the artistic fields leads inevitably to new forms of experimentation and the rethinking of the traditional ways, allowing them however to be expressed and valued. 
The main characteristics of technological art are of avoiding to interfere with its own material support and, because of its digital nature, replying with images to the actions. Perceived by the spectator these same images become part of the spectators’ experience background, feeding the artistic co-creation during the performance itself. The new art form based on art and technology is generated by the re-elaboration of different artistic forms, aiming to create a new dialog in the contemporary art fields. A dialog directed in researching a new awareness of digital art, that overcame recreational, scenographic or spectacular approaches.

Titled Compositional Phases, the fourth edition of Toolkit Festival will focus on the re-adaptation of the digital piece of art and on the modularity of the phases that constitute the project.

What we ask artists is to put in evidence the different phases of the project’s elaboration on-site in the Festival’s exposition spaces. The completed work will have to be, therefore, capable of expressing and communicating to the visitor at least one of the aspects that was part of the planning of the artwork and the execution of the different phases: from the technological re-adaptation of the work to its digital representation version in the exposition spaces that will host the Festival.

All the Association activities are self-funded, free and open to everybody. Even a small donation will help us sustain the organizational and running expenses of the Festival, and promote young artists from all over the word. All the donations will be fully reinvested in the production of the Festival, to support the expenses of materials, promotion and accomodation of the participating artists. 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT 
Toolkit Staff

For more infos visit our website
www.toolkitfestival.com 

                                                         Aurora Meccanica, La Gabbia (Toolkit 2011)

All the donations will be fully reinvested in the production of the Festival, to support the expenses of materials, promotion and accomodation of the participating artists. THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT Toolkit StaffFor more infos visit our websitewww.toolkitfestival.com                                                          Aurora Meccanica, La Gabbia (Toolkit 2011)

story:
Short Summary

No Strings Theatre is asking for your help as this year’s Summer Intensive students prepare to mount their production of the musical Little Women (music, Jason Howland; lyrics, Mindi Dickstein) at the Toronto Centre for the Arts.

No Strings Theatre has been in operation since 2005 and is dedicated to providing creative musical theatre training (integrating singing, acting, and dancing skills), pit orchestra training, and performance opportunities to youth ages 13-21. We provide an opportunity for youth to be involved in a professionally run musical theatre production, while offering them support and structure for creative expression, development of performance skills, and instruction in all aspects of stage production. In addition, No Strings Theatre offers a mentoring program that offers career opportunities for emerging production artists.

How You Can Help

An important part of the experience for our students -- and also for our emerging production artists -- is being able to stage our musical in a professional theatre. This year we would like to take Little Women to the Studio Theatre at the Toronto Centre for the Arts. The theatre has been very generous in acknowledging our budget limitations, but there are still significant costs associated with this choice. That’s where your donation can make a very big difference!


It will only take 1 person at $1000, 4 people at $500, 10 people at $100, 10 people at $50, and 20 people at $25 to help us achieve our $5000 goal.

What You Get

Every donation is a winner! Our list of perks includes a tax receipt, recognition in our programs, show tickets, advertising opportunities, and even dinner with one of the directors!

The Impact

The opportunity to develop a skill, to stand and take a bow, can change a life forever. No Strings Theatre’s Summer Intensive program brings together professional directors and choreographers to work with our students in a welcoming, inclusive, and supportive six-week program. The program culminates in the staging of our full-scale musical production at a professional theatre venue, and the result is magical. For our students and their families, it’s a dream-come-true moment. Our participants also experience growth in their social skills, team skills, self-confidence, and just the sheer joy of acting, singing, and dancing on stage.

We Are Thankful for Your Support

Denise Williams, Founding Artistic Director of No Strings Theatre: 

I would like to thank everyone for their efforts and contributions with last year's campaign.

Thanks to your generous support, we have been able to get off to a great start this year!  We have recently been accepted into the Toronto Artscape community, and through this new partnership, we have taken a new office space at the at the Artscape Wychwood Barns.  We also have obtained some funding through Youth Employment Services which is assisting us to support and supplement the cost of our new summer student administrative and creative team. Yes, this is definitely a year of new beginnings!

Last year, with the help of your generous donations, we were we able to balance the budget, supplement our scholarship funds for limited income families, and maintain the integrity and quality of our program.

This season we would like to acknowledge the generous support of the Toronto Centre for the Arts.

I hope that we can count on your continued support for No Strings Theatre as we grow and expand our programming for our wonderful, creative, inspiring students!


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word and make some noise about our campaign!!!

story:
The Project 

For two months in 2014, I will be working on my artistic residency in the oldest continually inhabited city in Europe, Cádiz. My residency has two clear outcomes:

The first is to create an exhibition for the end of the residency in Cádiz. This goal I am completely self-funding and am prepared to make this outcome happen!

The second outcome is where I need your help:

I am creating an artist book featuring a series of interviews, prose and letters from contemporary Spanish artists, curators, economists, art theorists, traffic engineers, flight instructors, jewellers, dancers and politics students to create a look at how and why contemporary artists choose to study, and create artwork about the city of Cádiz. 

This book aims to discuss how we come to value cultural capital and artists in society and how living in the oldest inhabited city in Europe affects individuals on a daily basis. 

This book will be a print run of 500 books, printed both (page for page) in Spanish and English, which will be distributed in Spanish and Australian independent bookstores and library collections. This book is a focused study on the artistic impacts of living in Cádiz, and a wider look at how we can relate to our identity through the place we call home. I am truly passionate about creating this book, and any help you could give to bring this book to life would be wonderful. 


A bit about me

My name is Beth, I am an emerging artist from Australia working with photographs and sculptural installation. By the time this campaign ends, I will have completed my degree in Fine Art (Photography) at the Victorian College of the Arts and am committed to continuing to exhibit and further my artistic practice. I have recently been given the incredible opportunity to work interrupted at a residency in Cádiz, in southwest Spain, with the dedicated group of artists at the Linea De Costa Residency . This residency will take place for all of June and July of 2014. This incredible opportunity is what brings me here, to ask for your help today! 


The Impact

By supporting this campaign, you're helping to further enrich Cádiz's cultural heritage and emerging community of local artists, if you donate to help create this book, you are literally helping bring the words of emerging contemporary artists and theorists to life. 

The importance of documenting, and transcribing the development of how we negotiate our identity and sense of home, or place, is truly underrated. This book aims to provide a sense of the fragility that comes with having to identify with one place on this earth, which makes the book a universal theme that we all (sometimes struggle) come to terms with. It is one thing to visit places and see how others live, but I am asking for you to help me take this notion further by asking questions and creating a cohesive piece of history for the future. 

Venture Capital After Hours, Italy, Type C Print, 2012

The Budget

I am working very hard (as all Australian artists do), to self-fund this residency and research. The only area I am seeking your help with is publishing the artists book. I believe that investing in artists, such as myself, takes trust and respect, so I have provided a transparent breakdown of my budget for this project:


Publishing the Artbook (inc. printing, binding, freight): EURO 2250

English > Spanish  Translator: 150 

Travel to Cadiz from Melbourne: EURO 1000

Materials (film, processing, drawing supplies): EURO 200

Printing of photographs: EURO 500

Freight of artwork: EURO 500

Travel expenses (visa, insurance etc.) EURO 150

Total in Euros: 4750

Children Playing In Front of the Wall in Palestine, Type C Print, 2012.


What You Get! Your help = my gratitude (and stuff sent to you!)

Firstly, if you do decide to donate, I would like to express my sincere thanks for your help - these gestures (large or small), are incredibly helpful and mean so much! 

  • If you decide to donate, I will personally make you a handmade thank you card and send it to you! The card features a print of one of my photographs.

  • Each donation will be received by my sincere appreciation, and I have set aside a number of archival, inkjet, photographic prints I am giving away as a way to thank you for your help. You can see the plethora of prints in the Rewards Column. 

  • For some of the larger donations, I will be giving special photographic prints of artworks I make at the residency in Cadiz.


  • There are other ways you can help than by donating! You could...

    • Copy the link to this campaign on your social networks so others can read about the Cadiz Artists book! 
    • Chat to your family and friends about this campaign, help me make some noise! 

    Thank you so much for taking the time to read through my project. 
    Beth
