story:
The Psychology of Bullying: A Search for Self-Acceptance

I was bullied from day one in Kindergarten. I remember it so clearly: Sitting next to another girl named Jessica I didn't yet know, the large open windows streaming in light from the gorgeous day outside. We were playing with puppets, and at the end of play period, Mrs. Gump, our teacher, told the class that it was time to clean up. The other girl kept playing, and when I repeated what Mrs. Gump had said, she bit me on the arm.

I don't remember what happened after that incident, but all those little things kept building up. An older girl on the bus telling me that I had a horrible voice and that I should stop singing, other kids teasing and ignoring me. By middle school, my classmates were spreading rumors about me, kicking me out of groups and conversations, making fun of me for the way I dressed or talked...and in one case, pushing me down the stairs.

I had thought that it stopped for the most part when I got to high school, but then one of my classmates, a jock I didn't know very well, came up to me and told me that one of my close friends was ridiculing me in front of one of her classes. He wanted me to know that she wasn't a true friend and he didn't want to see me hurt by her. It meant so much to me that he had done that.

About the Project

This project is going to consist of a combination of dark room and digital prints in black and white. My own body will be the subject matter, because of much of what happened to me was psychological, hidden scars that I want to make visible. My goal in creating this body of work is to discover just how far being bullied has affected my life, and with the hopes of coming to grips with at least a part of this, and begin the process of healing.

The body of work will consist of a semester-long journey of research, creation and discovery culminating in a series of 7-10 prints to be displayed in a gallery opening in early December 2012. With this work and research, I will also be writing a 15-25 page senior comp paper detailing my research, the work I have done, and the developments the work has brought about in my life. 

All of the funds raised here will go towards my supply and equipment costs: a light meter for my film camera, necessary repairs to my DSLR camera, film, the photo paper on which I will print, mounting, and frames for the works, as well as any supplies I may use in the images I produce.

About The Exhibit

Where: The Bownman Penelec Megahan Art Galleries of Allegheny College, 520 North Main Street, Meadville, PA 16335

When: Opening Reception: Tuesday, December 4, 7-9PM
Exhibition Dates: December 4 – 12, 2012

Gallery Hours: 12:30-5:00 Tuesday through Friday
1:30-5:00 Saturday
2:00-4:00 Sunday

Can Backers Follow the Project-in-Progress?

Absolutely! I will be posting blogs with my thoughts and progress on my website throughout the semester. Once the project has been completed, the prints up in the gallery and the paper printed and bound, I will create a space dedicated to this project on my website so that those unable to back my project and (in some cases) receive pieces of it, or who want to go back and look at it, will be able to. It will also be possible for people to discuss and comment on the page, in the hopes of some sort of dialogue on bullying coming from it. Everyone who backs this project will also receive a copy of my final 15-25 page paper.

My website: http://mindscastshadows.wordpress.com/

About Your Help

With your help I will be able to fully realize this body of work that will allow me to understand more readily the depth of the effects of bullying on my psyche. Any contribution will help, even the smallest. Printing and framing such a large body of work is an expensive and almost impossible goal to reach with almost no funds. This is why I'm asking my family, friends, friends of family and friends of friends to, please, support me in this important project.

About the Perks

On the right you'll see a list of rewards and incentives for your donation. They range from $1 to $200, but you can donate whatever amount you want, even if it is not listed. You can choose which reward you want to receive of any your donation amount and lower.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand how difficult it is when you find a project you'd love to help out but just don't have the funds to do so. If that's the case for you, please let people know about my project! Blogs, facebook, twitter, email, word of mouth...anything you can do to help would be wonderful!

Thank you all! Feel free to contact me if you have any questions.

-Anna Sobolov Good

story:
About Rachel

Rachel Selekman is an artist who makes sculpture and works on paper, and she’s been doing it, well, all her life, but you could say professionally since she received her BFA in 1985. A pretty long time no matter how you slice it. Trust me, I know, as I’m her.

On August 8, 2013, I’ll be turning the big “5” “0” and it’s time to survey my artistic career thus far and put it in print. That means publish my first monograph, a survey catalogue that will show the development of my sculpture and works on paper from the late 1980s to the present. 

About the Catalogue

The catalogue, called “Rachel Selekman: Making Connections,” with a print run of 1,000, will be filled with more than forty images of my sculpture and works on paper, so you’ll really get to see how my work has evolved over the years. It will include two essays, which will provide insight into why I do what I do, including my inspiration, interest in everyday objects, personal iconography, working method, and relationship to other artists and art movements, both past and present. It’ll be a good read!

One essay will be written by Margaret Mathews-Berenson, who is also organizing a traveling exhibition of my work, and I’m working on securing the second writer now. Of course, it will also include my biography. And it could very well include your name on the acknowledgment page (see the 5th perk). The catalogue will be published by the end of 2013.

Why a Catalogue?

Because it will be an amazingly helpful tool as well as a lasting document, showing my artistic accomplishments during the first half of my career.

Yes, it’s true that I’ve had numerous solo shows, that my works been included in even more group exhibitions all over the world, and that it’s in many private and public collections, including New York’s Museum of Modern Art, but there’s still much more to accomplish, lots of people in the ever-expanding art world who have never seen what I make, and, fundamentally, art is to be out in the world and this catalogue will help me get it out there—with your support!

It will also be a great complement to my website. The book will get folks intrigued and then they can go to my website to see even more work, read lots of reviews, my artist statement, and see the very latest work. It will also be a valuable accompaniment to my traveling show, which Margaret Mathews-Berenson is organizing as I mentioned above.

This Campaign

I’ve given this campaign a lot of thought. And in thinking about it and planning it, it dawned on me that it’s really another expression, or form, of my art. My work has always been a means of communication, a way to connect. For instance, many of the sculptures reach out to the viewer, drawing you in and enveloping you. The everyday objects I use (purses and watering cans) are familiar and make the work approachable, and often humorous, as these objects are absurd in their new manifestations. The works on paper entice with their compositions, materials, and intricate process. The point is, I want the viewer to have a personal, unique experience/connection with my art, and I also want to connect with you through this campaign, because you’re my friends, family, peers, colleagues, and fellow artists, or you’re supporting me because someone we know in common thought you’d be interested in this project. So thanks for taking this ride with me, and for your love and support.

Your Impact

Is huge! Your contirbutions are going to help me, a devoted, hardworking artist, by impacting the development of my work and my career in a tangible way. And by doing so, you more broadly acknowledge that art matters and is an integral and critical part of our society.

As for the particulars, your donations will pay for all the costs to produce the catalogue: the graphic designer, two writers, printing (which alone is about $10,000), an editor, postage and envelopes, and photography. (Photography too is a significant expense, but it’s critical. The images have to top-notch, and photography has changed so much. Remember film? Remember the first digital cameras? Well, I’ll have to have some of my older work reshot and slides and 4 x 5 transparencies professionally scanned, plus there’s new work to be photographed as well.)

Oh, yeah, and you’ll be giving me the best 50th birthday present ever!

Are You Turning Fifty This Year?

If you make a contribution to this campaign and were born in 1963, please include in the comments section the month and day of your birthday. I've got something special in store for you.

story:
What's our story?

Embarrassed.  That's the word 4th grader Galaneicia used to describe her feelings toward her school- Kirkpatrick Enhanced Option  (KEOS).  Her sentiment is the inspiration behind our mural project idea...

Galaneicia, who ignited it all!

Galaneicia's disheartening confession was overheard while at a Schwab Elementary debate tournament.  Our students were floored by Schwab's incredible murals plastered throughout each hall.  This prompted Galaneicia to admit how embarrassed she'd be for Kirkpatrick to host such an event.  She did not want other students to see where she goes to school.  We aim to change these negative impression of Kirkpatrick by putting up unique designs that showcase our incredible spirit!

Hey, y'all!

Hi! I'm Devon Murrie and I teach at the amazing Kirkpatrick Elementary in East Nashville.   We're working hard to bring in awesome and current wall art that transforms the inside of our school into a pretty and positive environment where great learning can occur.  I’ve fallen in love with this place. If you read on, I’m sure you will too!  

Seriously.. scroll down and feel your heart melt.

Help bring Nathan Brown's explosive creativity to Kirkpatrick!
Halsan :)

What is this? A school of child models?

We are totally playing the "cute kid" card.  We’ve stuffed our video with enough adorable faces and student testimony (not featured: Sarah McLachlan vocals and puppies) to tug on your heartstrings.   If not, what are you? A robot?

Just kidding!!

We do hope that our video gives you a brief, although incomplete, glimpse into student life at Kirkpatrick. We want to brag on all of the shiny, happy faces pictured above who smile in spite of spending the majority of their day in a school with lackluster features.  

Get to the nitty gritty! 

What's the plan?

This July 2013 we will create 7 murals that are both current and relatable to our stellar, student population!  The murals are a collaboration with graffiti masterminds and are founded in student designs.  Each unique work will focus on motivating students and promoting academic growth.  They will also be gorgeous--Bonus points!

We need to raise $4,000 to cover all costs and make this project a reality.  Our campaign is all-or-nothing. That means if we don't reach our total, we get zero funding (and you won't be charged).  We need a lot of community support and promotion to successfully fund the murals.

What will my donation go towards?

We need your help to securely cover the following project details:

-Paint and painting supplies for artists and volunteers,

-Opening the school during the summer,

-Stencil art materials and production fees

-Covering fees from Indiegogo and payment transactions

In return for your generous donations, you will receive some of the perks packages described on the upper-right side of the page.  We love the graffiti artists' work so much that we want to share it with you all- check 'em out!

More background information, please.

Sure thing!

Most of the kids at KEOS live in James A Cayce Homes- the Federal Government housing program directly behind our building.  Not only will Kirkpatrick's murals impact students' lives, but our proximity to the neighborhood allows the project's scope to reach our surrounding community.  Gotta love that!

John Partipilo / The Tennessean

Even amongst the incredible strengths of our Cayce community, many of our kids experience difficult and unstable situations.  School is supposed to represent the safe and enriching place where students' dreams can flourish and they feel encouraged. Yet many of our students are all too aware of our uninspired structure and they feel ashamed of their learning environment.

We know that for academics, aesthetics are not usually at the top of a to-do list.  However, there is a lot of research that supports the effect of an art-filled environment on student achievement.  And who doesn't want students to succeed?  Again with the robots.  So let’s bring in some paint, y'all!

 

Grade A artists.

Who is involved?

In order for this to have the amazing outcome the children deserve, we have to assemble an A-Team of artists!  We’re not just grabbing anyone off the street to lead this project… 

...okay, so actually we are. 

Legit street artists to be specific.  We’ve called in reinforcements from Nathan Brown and WorkForce Rebellion's Audie Adams (AudRoc as he's known amongst cooler crowds).  They are two amazing street muralists known for their vibrant, larger-than-life works painted around Nashville and inside a few lucky schools.  "Don’t believe me? Just watch!" Click the image below to get an idea of what we're talking about.

 
We know.  They're incredibly cool cats.

We've put some of our own cats on the job too!  Our Kirkpatrick Cougars submitted their ideas to Nathan and Audie as student-initiated guides for their mural designs. 

Growing the next generation's Picasso.
Student artwork! Note the Sponge Bob.

Thanks to Nathan, Audie, and many others around the city, Nashville is becoming a proud hub for public art.  If we value the city enough to beautify even the most forgotten buildings, then surely we can value our students enough to awaken pride in places of great importance, like schools.  Right?  Right!

Check out all of Nathan's and Audie's works on this page as well as their site links.  We hope they give you an idea of how great your reward paintings will be!

A glimpse of genius.

Why we need you.

You've heard our story and seen our vision.  We have all the pieces in place to make this project meaningful, except one.  We need your help to jump a major hurdle and show students like Galaneicia we can bring this dream to life.  Join in as an honorary Cougar and create an impact that extends beyond the beautification of a school hallway.  Together we can generate student achievement in a way that is creative and long-lasting! 

Ways to help:

- Donate a contribution to our project page 

- Spread the word by any means available (carrier pigeon, facebook status, etc.)

Updates:

If you partner with us, you can expect silly project updates along the way!  You will get an inside look at mural production, student reactions, and of course the finished product!

Help us provide a brand new school to students this Fall and create the community kickoff of a lifetime!

 

 

Potential risks and challenges:

As with any project, there is the possibility for obstacles and delays. As it currently stands, the project is set to be completed over a handful of days in early-mid July 2013 in time for the start of the school year on August 1! We will do everything in our power to adhere to our set timeline for both the project and incentives packages. Nathan and Audie are kind of a big deal so if production of reward paintings gets backed up we will notify you ASAP! 

But fear not! We already have the crew of local artists who are more than capable of completing the job. We have approval from our administration and examples of similar project success stories within our school district. Lastly, we have a very hyped student body and staff. All that to say, if something should arise that puts our plan off track, you all will be the first to know about how we're fixing it!  We strive for ultimate transparency in all that we do with this project.


Your faith and support is incredible! :)
